title: Agreement between the EU and Morocco concerning reciprocal liberalisation measures on agricultural products and fishery products - Greens/ALE, GUE/NGL: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the agreement between the EU and Morocco concerning reciprocal liberalisation measures on agricultural products and fishery products
background: The EU and Morocco negotiated reciprocal agricultural and fishery trade measures under existing Euro-Mediterranean agreements, amid UN resolutions on Western Sahara’s decolonization and post-Arab Spring calls for equitable development. The Parliament will discuss the agreement’s alignment with international law, economic impacts on regional producers, and human rights considerations.

stances.stance:
EPP rejects the agreement's inclusion of Western Sahara territories as firmly conflicting with international law and EPP's commitment to UN-recognized self-determination principles.  
EPP opposes the tariff liberalization framework for enabling unfair competition against EU farmers through lower production standards and documented customs fraud vulnerabilities.  
EPP condemns the absence of binding environmental safeguards, contradicting EPP's agricultural policy requiring equivalent ecological compliance for all market entrants.  
EPP highlights the issue's exposure of child labor violations in Moroccan agriculture as irreconcilable with EPP's human rights benchmarks for trade partners.  
EPP demands strict reciprocity in market access terms, rejecting current asymmetries that disadvantage EU meat and dairy exports to Morocco.

GREEN_EFA strongly accepts the issue’s explicit exclusion of Western Sahara from the agreement, aligning perfectly with their commitment to upholding international law and the Sahrawi people’s right to self-determination.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the emphasis on sustainable development and food sovereignty, which directly advances their priority of protecting small-scale producers and ecosystems in both EU and Mediterranean regions.  
GREEN_EFA endorses the call for rigorous sustainability impact assessments, proposing enhanced monitoring mechanisms to prevent child labor and water resource exploitation in agricultural supply chains.  
GREEN_EFA approves the demand for separate agreements with Western Sahara’s legitimate representatives, reinforcing their stance against Morocco’s illegal occupation and resource extraction.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s alignment with their advocacy for gender-equitable trade policies, urging stricter labor rights clauses in future negotiations to address systemic inequalities.

ALDE rejects the issue’s opposition to the EU-Morocco agreement, emphasizing the €100 million annual gain for EU exporters and enhanced market access as critical for economic reciprocity.  
ALDE opposes the exclusion of Western Sahara from trade terms, asserting that integrated regional cooperation aligns with Morocco’s democratic reforms and post-Arab Spring stability.  
ALDE dismisses claims of insufficient labor and environmental safeguards, citing enforceable commitments to ILO conventions and phytosanitary standards within the agreement.  
ALDE criticizes demands for separate Sahrawi representation, arguing this undermines EU-Morocco diplomatic trust and broader development goals in North Africa.  
ALDE fundamentally condemns renegotiation, viewing the agreement as a strategic tool to reduce poverty and strengthen EU influence in the Southern Mediterranean.

SD firmly opposes the agreement’s inclusion of Western Sahara as an unlawful annexation violating international law and Sahrawi self-determination rights.  
SD rejects the failure to address Morocco’s exploitation of occupied territories’ resources, contradicting UN issues cited in the issue.  
SD condemns the absence of binding mechanisms to prevent child labor and environmental degradation linked to Moroccan agricultural exports.  
SD highlights the agreement’s threat to EU small-scale producers’ livelihoods through unregulated market access, ignoring issue demands for reciprocity and compensation.  
SD opposes the Commission’s refusal to separate Western Sahara from negotiations, undermining calls for direct engagement with its legitimate representatives.

ECR rejects the issue's opposition to the EU-Morocco agreement as firmly rejecting with their stance that trade liberalization drives economic stability and job creation in North Africa.  
ECR opposes conditioning trade agreements on Western Sahara's status, asserting this conflates political disputes with economic cooperation contrary to their principle of market-driven growth.  
The issue overlooks critical aspects of ECR's position by dismissing tariff reductions' role in preventing youth migration to Europe through local employment opportunities.  
ECR condemns the issue's demand to separate Western Sahara from Morocco in trade terms as inconsistent with their view that Sahrawi producers benefit from EU market access.  
 ECR arguments emphasize immediate job losses from rejecting agreements, directly contradicting the issue's focus on human rights and self-determination.

GUE_NGL strongly accepts the issue's condemnation of Morocco's illegal occupation and resource exploitation in Western Sahara, aligning perfectly with their commitment to anti-colonial principles and international law.  
GUE_NGL approves the demand for separate agreements with Western Sahara's representatives, effectively advancing their priority of self-determination for occupied territories.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue's exposure of corporate-driven trade harms as crucial to protecting small-scale producers, proposing enhanced monitoring of multinational land acquisitions in Morocco's agricultural sector.  
GUE_NGL endorses linking trade to labor rights enforcement, urging explicit reference to ILO Convention 138 on child labor given UNICEF's cited data on Moroccan education gaps.  
GUE_NGL commends the rejection of fisheries protocol extensions, suggesting stricter traceability requirements to prevent Western Sahara resource plundering under this agreement.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the EU-Morocco agreement on agricultural and fishery products, opposing its inclusion of Western Sahara, which is not recognized as part of Morocco under international law, citing the International Court of Justice’s 1975 opinion and UN resolutions affirming Western Sahara’s right to self-determination. It criticized the agreement for undermining sustainable development, food sovereignty, and small-scale producers in both regions, highlighting risks to ecosystems, water resources, and labor rights, particularly noting UNICEF reports that 1.5 million Moroccan children lack access to education and child labor persists. The resolution urged renegotiation to prioritize mutual benefits, regional cooperation, and inclusive stakeholder involvement, emphasizing sustainability impact assessments to avoid social and environmental harm. It condemned Morocco’s illegal occupation of Western Sahara and exploitation of its resources, demanding EU adherence to international law and separate agreements with Western Sahara’s legitimate representatives. The Parliament also rejected the 2011 fisheries protocol extension and broader free trade approaches, advocating instead for policies supporting decent jobs, gender equality, and value-chain development to address economic fragility in Southern Mediterranean and EU regions.

title: Agreement between the EU and Morocco concerning reciprocal liberalisation measures on agricultural products and fishery products - report Bové: RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of an Agreement in the form of an Exchange of Letters between the European Union and the Kingdom of Morocco concerning reciprocal liberalisation measures on agricultural products, processed agricultural products, fish and fishery products, the replacement of Protocols 1, 2 and 3 and their Annexes and amendments to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Kingdom of Morocco, of the other part
background: The EU and Morocco, under their 2000 Euro-Mediterranean Agreement and 2008 advanced status partnership, engaged in negotiations on reciprocal agricultural and fishery trade liberalization amid Morocco’s 2011 constitutional reforms and regional Arab Spring developments. The Parliament will discuss approving a new bilateral agreement modifying existing trade protocols for agricultural and fishery products.

stances.stance:
EPP supports the agreement as a strategic step to reinforce Euro-Mediterranean stability, aligning with commitments to democratic reforms in Morocco.  
EPP advises strengthening monitoring mechanisms for tariff quotas and entry price systems to prevent fraudulent underdeclaration of Moroccan imports.  
EPP requests amendments to ensure reciprocity in market access, particularly addressing residual duties on EU meat exports to Morocco.  
EPP highlights the necessity of environmental and social standards parity to prevent unfair competition against EU farmers facing stricter regulations.  
EPP notes concerns from southern European agricultural sectors but emphasizes reliance on Commission safeguards for market disruptions.

GREEN_EFA totally disapproves the agreement for failing to explicitly exclude Western Sahara's territories, directly violating international law on self-determination of occupied peoples.  
GREEN_EFA rejects the trade terms that incentivize export-driven agribusinesses over small farmers, exacerbating social inequality and environmental degradation in both EU and Moroccan regions.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the absence of binding clauses to prevent child labor in agricultural exports, contradicting core commitments to human rights and ethical trade practices.  
GREEN_EFA disputes the agreement's legitimacy in negotiating Sahrawi resources, noting its complicity in Morocco's illegal exploitation of occupied Western Sahara's fisheries and farmlands.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue's failure to address post-Arab Spring democratic reforms, undermining stated EU goals of promoting political transformation in North Africa.

ALDE strongly approves the enhanced trade reciprocity framework as aligning with their commitment to economic partnership-driven democratization in the Mediterranean region.  
ALDE proposes reinforcing Annex II monitoring mechanisms to verify Morocco's application of ILO conventions on agricultural labor standards.  
ALDE applauds the tariff reduction structure for creating mutual economic benefits while urging quarterly reporting on Saharan product origin certifications.  
ALDE recommends inserting explicit reference to UNSC Resolution 690 in Protocol 2 to confirm trade measures don't prejudice Western Sahara's self-determination process.  
ALDE endorses the quota system design but suggests tripling phytosanitary inspection sampling rates during initial implementation phases.

SD supports the agreement as a strategic tool to reinforce economic stability and democratic progress in Morocco following the Arab Spring, aligning with SD's commitment to fostering equitable development.  
SD advises implementing rigorous monitoring of agricultural quotas and price mechanisms to prevent market disruptions for EU farmers, particularly in sensitive sectors like horticulture.  
SD emphasizes the necessity of ongoing impact assessments to ensure reciprocal benefits, including safeguards for small-scale Moroccan producers and EU agricultural interests.  
SD highlights the importance of explicitly addressing Western Sahara resource rights in future dialogues, urging the Commission to maintain transparency in regional benefit tracking.  
SD proposes establishing an EU compensation fund for affected farmers through CAP adjustments, ensuring dignity and economic security while upholding trade liberalization goals.

ECR supports the agreement's role in fostering economic growth and stability in Morocco, aligning with their emphasis on job creation and regional security through enhanced trade relations.  
ECR advises incorporating safeguards to protect EU fisheries from market disruption, ensuring competition aligns with sustainable practices and the Common Fisheries Policy.  
ECR highlights the importance of maintaining Sahrawi employment opportunities, arguing that rejecting such agreements risks unintended economic harm to local communities.  
ECR suggests explicit clarification in the agreement's text to confirm it does not prejudice the self-determination process in Western Sahara, addressing geopolitical sensitivities.  
ECR endorses reciprocal tariff reductions as mutually beneficial, particularly for expanding EU exports of processed goods to Moroccan markets.

GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the agreement for prioritizing profits of European multinationals and Moroccan elites over small farmers and workers, conflicting with their stance on social justice and equitable trade.  
GUE_NGL rejects the inclusion of Western Sahara's resources, violating international law and legitimizing Morocco's occupation, contrary to their anti-colonial principles.  
GUE_NGL condemns the agreement's failure to address Morocco's suppression of labor rights, including union bans and worker dismissals, undermining their commitment to workers' solidarity.  
GUE_NGL denounces the intensified pressure on Mediterranean small-scale producers, exacerbating market inequalities and environmental degradation, opposing their vision of sustainable local agriculture.  
GUE_NGL challenges the disregard for democratic accountability in Morocco, ignoring low electoral participation and protests, inconsistent with their demand for trade conditioned on human rights.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its consent to the conclusion of the Agreement between the EU and Morocco on reciprocal liberalization measures for agricultural products, processed agricultural goods, fish, and fishery products, which replaces Protocols 1, 2, and 3 and their annexes while amending the Euro-Mediterranean Association Agreement. The resolution, based on draft Council decision 15975/2010 and draft Agreement 15974/2010, endorsed updated trade terms to enhance bilateral relations, following a recommendation from the Committee on International Trade and input from the Committees on Agriculture and Rural Development and Fisheries. It mandated the Parliament’s President to communicate this decision to the EU Council, Commission, member states, and Moroccan authorities, ensuring alignment with the revised provisions.

title: Agreements on trade in bananas: RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of a Geneva Agreement on Trade in Bananas between the European Union and Brazil, Colombia, Costa Rica, Ecuador, Guatemala, Honduras, Mexico, Nicaragua, Panama, Peru and Venezuela and of an Agreement on Trade in Bananas between the European Union and the United States of America
background: The EU faced prolonged WTO disputes with the US and Latin American countries over preferential banana import terms for African, Caribbean, and Pacific (ACP) states, violating non-discrimination principles. The Parliament will discuss concluding agreements to resolve these disputes through revised tariffs and financial support for ACP exporters.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly advocates the issue's balanced approach to trade liberalization while safeguarding vulnerable EU banana producers and ACP economies, aligning with EPP's commitment to equitable global markets.  
EPP proposes enhancing the POSEI financial framework to address tariff reductions below 2006 projections, ensuring compensation reflects actual market impacts on outermost regions like the Canary Islands and Madeira.  
EPP applauds the €190 million BAM programme as critical for maintaining ACP countries' competitiveness, directly advancing EPP's development priorities in EU partner nations.  
EPP emphasizes strict monitoring of Mercosur negotiations to prevent disproportionate concessions that could undermine EU agricultural sectors beyond bananas.  
EPP urges accelerated implementation of environmental safeguards in the agreement to ensure parity between Latin American and EU production standards.

EFD fully disapproves the issue's continuation of EU protectionist frameworks that sparked costly WTO disputes, contradicting their free trade principles  
EFD rejects the €190 million BAM programme as institutionalizing market distortions rather than enabling genuine ACP competitiveness through deregulation  
The proposal's tariff reduction schedule fails to dismantle the EU's "preference erosion" mechanisms that EFD deems incompatible with global trade fairness  
EFD condemns the issue's validation of bureaucratic quality standards (e.g., banana curvature rules) as emblematic of EU regulatory overreach  
This agreement's WTO negotiation clauses directly conflict with EFD's demand for unilateral termination of all banana trade restrictions rather than managed liberalization

GREEN_EFA opposes fundamentally the tariff reduction framework for reinforcing US multinational dominance, which contradicts their mandate to protect small-scale producers and food sovereignty.  
GREEN_EFA rejects the insufficient BAM financial package, noting its failure to address systemic socioeconomic vulnerabilities in ACP nations reliant on EU market access.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s inconsistency with sustainable production goals, as it lacks binding clauses to promote ecological practices or local economic resilience.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the agreement’s neglect of preference erosion mitigation, which directly undermines ACP countries’ competitive viability against subsidized multinational corporations.  
GREEN_EFA demands radical WTO rule reforms to prioritize equitable trade over corporate profit, aligning with their 2023 manifesto on decolonizing economic structures.

ALDE strongly advocates the issue's balanced approach to resolving long-standing banana trade disputes while safeguarding ACP economies through targeted financial assistance.  
ALDE applauds the €190 million BAM programme as aligning perfectly with ALDE's longstanding commitment to equitable development and trade-driven economic diversification in vulnerable regions.  
ALDE emphasizes the historic significance of demonstrating EU coherence in multilateral negotiations, particularly in reconciling Latin American producer interests with ACP preferential access frameworks.  
ALDE proposes enhancing price transparency mechanisms to monitor potential consumer impacts in European markets without opposing the tariff reduction schedule.  
ALDE approves the issue's strategic linkage between tariff adjustments and WTO negotiation frameworks, effectively advancing ALDE's priority of rules-based trade modernization.

SD strongly upholds the €190 million BAM financial package, perfectly aligning with their commitment to safeguarding ACP countries’ economies and mitigating preference erosion through targeted competitiveness measures.  
SD applauds the issue’s structured tariff reductions and WTO negotiation framework, effectively advancing SD’s priority of balancing trade liberalization with protections for vulnerable producers.  
SD proposes enhancing the agreement by mandating explicit support for fair trade certification systems to ensure ethical labor practices and environmental sustainability in banana supply chains.  
SD emphasizes rigorous enforcement of EU competition laws to prevent multinational corporations from undermining small producers through predatory pricing or market monopolization.  
SD approves the requirement for a 2020 impact assessment, urging its expansion to include long-term monitoring of outermost regions’ producers and additional funding extensions if needed.

GUE_NGL rejects the scheduled MFN tariff reductions as they disproportionately benefit Latin American giants and US multinationals, undermining small producers in ACP countries and outermost European regions.  
GUE_NGL opposes the €190 million BAM package as a palliative measure that fails to prevent the socioeconomic ruin of ACP countries reliant on preferential EU market access.  
GUE_NGL absolutely condemns with the issue's neglect of specific support mechanisms for European banana producers, leaving them vulnerable to market inundation by multinational corporations.  
GUE_NGL condemns the agreement's alignment with WTO-driven globalization, which prioritizes trade liberalization over environmental and worker protections, contradicting their commitment to upward harmonization of labor rights.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue's failure to address preference erosion adequately, perpetuating inequalities that crush fragile economies in the Global South.

resolution: The European Parliament raised a resolution outlining a three-part agreement to address banana trade disputes and support affected economies, comprising a scheduled reduction of most-favoured nation (MFN) tariffs for banana exporters, a framework for addressing "tropical products" and mitigating "preference erosion" within ongoing WTO negotiations, and a €190 million financial assistance package under the Banana Accompanying Measures (BAM) programme to aid African, Caribbean, and Pacific (ACP) banana-exporting nations in adapting to market changes and enhancing competitiveness. The resolution emphasized balancing trade liberalization with safeguards for vulnerable economies, particularly through tariff adjustments and targeted support to mitigate socioeconomic impacts on ACP countries reliant on preferential access to the EU market.

title: EC-Uzbekistan partnership and cooperation agreement and bilateral trade in textiles: INTERIM REPORT on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Uzbekistan, of the other part, amending the Agreement in order to extend the provisions of the Agreement to bilateral trade in textiles, taking account of the expiry of the bilateral textiles Agreement
background: The EU-Uzbekistan Partnership and Cooperation Agreement, emphasizing human rights and market economy principles, coexists with longstanding allegations of forced child labor in Uzbekistan’s state-controlled cotton sector and environmental concerns over Aral Sea depletion. The Parliament will discuss amending the agreement to regulate bilateral textiles trade after prior arrangements expired.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly endorses the issue’s emphasis on leveraging trade agreements to enforce human rights reforms, aligning perfectly with EPP’s longstanding commitment to ethical globalization and rule-based international partnerships.  
EPP proposes making protocol approval conditional on unrestricted ILO access to monitor cotton production, ensuring compliance with anti-forced labor laws while maintaining trade continuity as a reform incentive.  
EPP applauds the linkage of fair textile trade to environmental sustainability, matching their 2023 manifesto priorities on combating ecological degradation through responsible economic engagement.  
EPP urges the Commission to develop a structured roadmap for technical assistance to modernize Uzbekistan’s agricultural sector, addressing root causes of labor exploitation through technology investment.  
EPP emphasizes the need for consistent human rights benchmarks across all EU trade partners, framing Uzbekistan’s scrutiny as a precedent to avoid double standards in future agreements.

EFD strongly endorses the issue's emphasis on eradicating forced child labor in Uzbek cotton production, aligning perfectly with EFD's longstanding commitment to ethical trade practices and human rights protections in EU partnerships.  
EFD urges immediate EU enforcement measures to convert parliamentary condemnation into actionable sanctions, proposing enhanced textile import verification protocols to ensure compliance with anti-forced labor clauses.  
EFD approves linking trade privileges to Uzbekistan’s measurable progress in dismantling state-coerced labor systems, particularly through reforms to cotton pricing mechanisms that perpetuate exploitation.  
EFD emphasizes the critical need for sustainable water management commitments, strongly endorsing the issue’s focus on reversing environmental degradation caused by irresponsible irrigation practices.  
EFD calls for quarterly monitoring reports to Parliament on Uzbekistan’s labor law implementation, ensuring continuous pressure aligns with the Partnership Agreement’s democratic conditionality requirements.

GREEN_EFA strongly accepts conditioning textile trade agreements on verifiable eradication of state-coerced child labor, aligning perfectly with their human rights and ethical trade principles.  
GREEN_EFA approves withholding parliamentary consent until Uzbekistan dismantles systemic school closures during harvests and demonstrates transparent age verification in cotton production.  
GREEN_EFA proposes enhancing independent monitoring mechanisms in Article 6 to verify compliance with ILO conventions beyond government-reported data.  
GREEN_EFA applauds linking market access to environmental remediation, particularly demanding measurable progress in restoring the Aral Sea basin through updated irrigation standards.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes that any bilateral textile quotas must include blockchain traceability requirements to exclude cotton harvested through forced labor.

ALDE strongly endorses leveraging the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement to demand immediate eradication of forced child labor, aligning perfectly with ALDE's longstanding commitment to human rights-based trade policies.  
ALDE approves enhanced monitoring mechanisms for cotton traceability, proposing an amendment to mandate third-party verification of supply chains as a critical enhancement opportunity.  
ALDE strongly endorses suspending Uzbekistan’s GSP privileges until ILO inspectors gain unfettered access to cotton fields, effectively advancing ALDE's priority of linking market access to labor rights compliance.  
ALDE applauds the issue’s environmental focus, urging accelerated implementation of sustainable irrigation reforms to reverse the Aral Sea crisis in line with ALDE’s 2023 water security manifesto pledges.  
ALDE calls for binding arbitration clauses in textile trade provisions to enforce accountability, reflecting ALDE’s strategic goal of embedding enforceable democratic conditionality in EU external agreements.

SD strongly agrees the issue’s demand for independent ILO monitoring to eradicate forced child labor in Uzbekistan, aligning perfectly with SD’s commitment to human rights and ethical trade.  
SD approves leveraging the partnership agreement to enforce legal reforms and sustainable water management, advancing SD’s environmental and governance priorities.  
SD endorses conditioning trade expansion on Uzbekistan’s implementation of ILO conventions, reflecting SD’s principle of linking market access to labor rights compliance.  
SD proposes amending the protocol to mandate transparency labels for EU textiles using Uzbek cotton, enhancing consumer awareness and corporate accountability.  
SD applauds the issue’s alignment with SD’s manifesto goals by addressing systemic exploitation and ecological neglect in Uzbekistan’s cotton sector.

GUE_NGL supports the issue’s emphasis on linking trade to human rights but insists on explicit preconditions for agreement ratification, including verified ILO access and eradication of forced child labor.  
GUE_NGL advises amending the protocol to mandate third-party monitoring of cotton supply chains, ensuring EU imports are decoupled from exploitative practices.  
GUE_NGL highlights contradictions in maintaining trade privileges under GSP+ while state-coerced labor persists, urging suspension of tariff reductions until reforms are independently verified.  
GUE_NGL proposes binding environmental clauses requiring Uzbekistan to adopt sustainable irrigation practices, addressing the Aral Sea crisis through EU-funded technical assistance.  
GUE_NGL stresses the need for punitive measures in Article 4 if Uzbekistan fails to dismantle production quotas incentivizing forced labor, aligning with ILO Convention 182.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding Uzbekistan’s compliance with international human rights and environmental standards, particularly citing systematic forced child labor in cotton harvesting despite government claims that such practices are limited to private farms and not state-sanctioned. It highlighted evidence from independent observers implicating state actors, including police and security forces, in coercing teachers and families to mobilize children for labor, contradicting Uzbekistan’s assertions. The resolution emphasized the need to revise government-set cotton prices and production quotas, which perpetuate resource limitations and incentivize forced labor. It linked fair trade to human rights, urging the EU to ensure Uzbek cotton exports are not underpinned by exploitative practices. Environmental degradation was also addressed, noting that inefficient irrigation and poor standards caused the Aral Sea’s volume to drastically shrink between 1990 and 2008. Parliament called on the EU to leverage the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement—which binds Uzbekistan to democratic principles, human rights, and market economy norms—to demand reforms, enforce anti-forced labor laws, promote sustainable water management, and align trade policies with ethical and environmental benchmarks.

title: EU trade and investment agreement negotiations with the US: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on EU trade and investment negotiations with the United States of America
background: Ongoing EU-US economic collaboration as major global traders, including the 2013 High Level Working Group's call for a comprehensive agreement to reduce trade barriers and regulatory differences, preceded parliamentary consideration. The Parliament will discuss launching negotiations for a transatlantic trade and investment partnership.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly advocates the TTIP's potential to generate €119 billion annual economic gains and strengthen transatlantic leadership in global standard-setting.  
EPP approves the issue's focus on eliminating non-tariff barriers through regulatory alignment in agriculture while proposing reinforced safeguards for geographical indications and the precautionary principle on GMOs.  
EPP endorses maintaining strict exclusion of audiovisual services from negotiations to protect European cultural identity under UNESCO conventions.  
EPP emphasizes the strategic imperative to accelerate regulatory cooperation frameworks for future legislation, aligning with transatlantic parliamentary dialogue mechanisms.  
EPP highlights the need to exclude defense procurement from the agreement to preserve EU industrial autonomy, converting concerns into procedural enhancement opportunities.

GREEN_EFA opposes fundamentally the issue's failure to mandate full public disclosure of TTIP negotiation texts  
GREEN_EFA rejects the investor-state dispute mechanisms that enable corporate challenges to democratic policymaking  
GREEN_EFA condemns the proposed regulatory convergence on agriculture as incompatible with EU GMO bans and precautionary principles  
GREEN_EFA declares the issue's growth projections irreconcilable with risks to public services and environmental standards  
GREEN_EFA demands binding clauses prohibiting chlorine-washed meat and hormone-treated beef imports as non-negotiable red lines

ALDE supports initiating TTIP negotiations to boost transatlantic economic integration but advises amending the mandate to explicitly exclude cultural and audiovisual services, preserving the EU’s UNESCO-backed cultural diversity protections.  
ALDE endorses regulatory convergence goals while proposing strengthened safeguards in Article 7(3) to prohibit mutual recognition of GMO products and enforce geographical indication protections against US market practices.  
ALDE emphasizes the necessity of maintaining high environmental standards, urging binding commitments in Annex B to align with EU REACH chemical regulations and Paris Agreement climate targets.  
ALDE highlights the importance of transparent stakeholder engagement, recommending a public consultation portal for real-time feedback and monthly parliamentary briefings during negotiations.  
ALDE cautions against accelerated timelines for sectoral agreements, stressing the need for thorough impact assessments on SMEs and labor markets to ensure balanced outcomes.

SD supports the issue's economic objectives to boost transatlantic trade and create jobs through tariff reduction and NTB removal, aligning with their industrial revitalization priorities.  
SD advises amending the mandate to explicitly exclude audiovisual services from negotiations, maintaining the EU's longstanding cultural exception policy as demonstrated in EU-Canada agreements.  
SD emphasizes requiring binding commitments to uphold the precautionary principle in agriculture and ILO labor standards, rejecting any equivalence mechanisms that could lower EU food safety rules.  
SD highlights the need for symmetrical regulatory convergence in financial services, opposing extraterritorial application of US regulations while preserving EU data privacy frameworks under GDPR.  
SD urges stricter parliamentary oversight mechanisms for each negotiation round, including mandatory impact assessments on social protections before concluding sectoral agreements.

ECR strongly endorses the issue’s focus on regulatory convergence in sectors like automotive, aligning with their commitment to mutual recognition of standards as a catalyst for reducing non-tariff barriers and unlocking transatlantic growth.  
ECR approves the prioritization of EU collective bargaining power in negotiations, emphasizing the strategic necessity of unified EU-US engagement over fragmented national approaches.  
ECR proposes enhancing transparency in addressing cultural sensitivities to ensure protections for audiovisual services do not inadvertently create new trade barriers, while maintaining market openness.  
ECR applauds the issue’s alignment with WTO principles and outward-looking trade policy, reflecting their advocacy for global competitiveness and rejection of protectionist rhetoric.  
ECR underscores the importance of maintaining a strict trade-centric scope in negotiations to avoid dilution by non-commercial issues, consistent with their efficiency-driven trade agenda.

GUE_NGL rejects the TTIP negotiations as fundamentally incompatible with democratic governance and social justice, citing the issue's failure to prohibit investor-state dispute mechanisms that prioritize corporate interests over public welfare.  
GUE_NGL opposes the proposed regulatory convergence in agriculture, declaring the issue's approach to GMOs and cloning irreconcilable with the precautionary principle and food sovereignty demands.  
GUE_NGL condemns the mandate's secrecy and lack of enforceable labor clauses, noting the issue's environmental standards contradict their 2022 manifesto requiring binding Paris Agreement alignment.  
GUE_NGL warns the agreement would accelerate privatization of public services, directly conflicting with their red lines on protecting EU cultural/audiovisual sectors from market liberalization.  
GUE_NGL asserts the issue's intellectual property framework facilitates biopiracy, mirroring ACTA's threats to digital rights and access to medicines denounced in their 2013 campaign.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the strategic and economic significance of deepening EU-US trade relations through a comprehensive Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP), emphasizing the potential for annual economic gains of EUR 119.2 billion for the EU and EUR 94.9 billion for the US, alongside a projected 28% increase in EU exports to the US. Highlighting the existing integration of markets, with daily bilateral trade of nearly EUR 2 billion and total investments exceeding EUR 2.394 trillion in 2011, the resolution stressed the need to address non-tariff barriers (NTBs), such as divergent regulatory standards and customs procedures, to unlock further growth, job creation, and competitiveness. It endorsed the High Level Working Group’s recommendations to enhance market access for goods, services, and public procurement, promote regulatory convergence in sectors like agriculture (noting sensitivities on GMOs, cloning, and the EU’s precautionary principle), financial services (emphasizing equivalence and minimizing extraterritoriality), and transport (addressing air and maritime restrictions). The resolution called for strong intellectual property protections, including geographical indications, and safeguards for EU cultural and audiovisual services, while ensuring alignment with labor and environmental standards, ILO principles, and data privacy rights under EU law. It urged transparency and stakeholder engagement throughout negotiations, prioritizing high-quality outcomes over speed, and affirmed Parliament’s role in scrutinizing the agreement and granting final consent under EU treaties.

title: EU trade negotiations with Japan: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on EU trade negotiations with Japan
background: The EU and Japan conducted economic assessments, summits, and public consultations (2009-2011) identifying regulatory trade barriers and mutual interest in closer integration. The Parliament will discuss initiating formal negotiations for a comprehensive EU-Japan trade agreement addressing tariff elimination and non-tariff barriers to deepen bilateral economic cooperation.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly accepts the issue's requirement for parliamentary oversight of negotiation mandates, aligning with their commitment to democratic trade governance while proposing enhanced committee consultation timelines.  
EPP approves the strategic prioritization of removing non-tariff barriers in automotive and rail sectors, urging explicit monitoring mechanisms mirroring the CARS 21 agreement's safeguard clauses.  
EPP endorses accelerated negotiations with Japan as critical for growth-oriented reforms, recommending structured three-year implementation deadlines to ensure Commission resource allocation.  
EPP applauds the agricultural protections framework, proposing strengthened provisions for mutual recognition of geographical indications and organic certification processes in the mandate.  
EPP emphasizes alignment with their 2023 transatlantic trade strategy principles, suggesting technical working groups to resolve sector-specific regulatory disparities during negotiations.

GREEN_EFA strongly agrees the issue’s demand for parliamentary consultation on the negotiation mandate, aligning perfectly with their commitment to democratic trade governance and institutional accountability.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the emphasis on transparency and lessons from past agreements like ACTA, which directly advances their priority of preventing opaque trade deals lacking public legitimacy.  
GREEN_EFA endorses the focus on non-tariff regulatory barriers over tariffs, effectively promoting sustainable economic integration consistent with multilateral trade principles.  
GREEN_EFA proposes enhancing the mandate by explicitly tying negotiations to a cohesive EU industrial strategy, ensuring alignment with long-term economic priorities like automotive sector transformation.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the necessity of rigorous ex-post impact assessments to validate claimed benefits, urging their formal inclusion in future negotiation frameworks to strengthen evidence-based policymaking.

ALDE rejects the issue's precondition requiring Japan to address regulatory barriers prior to negotiation authorization, viewing this as protectionist inertia that jeopardizes EU competitiveness.  
ALDE opposes fundamentally the linkage of Parliament’s formal position to Council authorization, arguing this procedural delay contradicts urgent economic needs for market expansion into Japan.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of geopolitical strategy by ignoring Japan’s pivot risk toward Trans-Pacific partners if EU hesitates, directly conflicting with ALDE’s free-trade acceleration principles.  
ALDE condemns the issue’s failure to balance safeguards with growth imperatives, noting its own insistence on provisional negotiation triggers (e.g., automotive sector reciprocity) offers superior crisis-response alignment.  
This framework’s rigidity in mandating pre-negotiation barrier removal disregards ALDE’s documented 2012 advocacy for concurrent barrier issue during talks, as outlined in written statement No 0016/2012.

SD strongly approves the issue’s emphasis on dismantling Japan’s non-tariff barriers, particularly in the automotive sector through UN convention adherence, tax benefit parity, and workshop access reforms.  
SD strongly approves requiring Japan to open its public procurement markets as essential for balanced economic integration, aligning with their commitment to reciprocal trade fairness.  
SD strongly endorses Parliament’s formal involvement in defining the negotiation mandate to ensure democratic oversight, reflecting treaty obligations and strategic prioritization of market access reforms.  
SD highlights the issue’s alignment with their economic priorities, noting Japan’s role as a strategic partner with complementary industrial bases and shared challenges like sustainable growth.  
SD proposes a September timeline for finalizing Parliament’s guidelines to strengthen the mandate’s clarity without opposing the agreement’s strategic value.

ECR opposes fundamentally the issue's requirement for parliamentary pre-approval of negotiation mandates as incompatible with efficient trade diplomacy.  
ECR rejects the issue's micromanagement of technical regulatory barriers like vehicle standards, which conflicts with their stance on expert-led negotiation processes.  
The proposal completely condemns with ECR's principle that elected officials should set strategic goals while delegating technical details to specialists.  
ECR highlights the issue's failure to address the operational impracticality of parliamentary involvement in granular issues like UNECE emissions compliance frameworks.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of ECR's trade policy by prioritizing procedural oversight over rapid market access achievements through Commission-led talks.

GUE_NGL slightly agrees the issue's framework but demands binding amendments to Article 3 prohibiting unilateral deregulation of consumer safety standards under trade barrier negotiations.  
GUE_NGL opposes the mandate's failure to include symmetrical protections for Japanese agricultural communities, requiring explicit safeguards against EU export dumping in Annex 2.  
GUE_NGL fundamentally rejects the issue's implicit acceptance of investor-state dispute mechanisms, insisting all references to private arbitration be struck from negotiation parameters.  
GUE_NGL requests revising Section 5 to mandate joint EU-Japan impact assessments on employment and public services before tariff reduction talks commence.  
GUE_NGL highlights contradictions with social solidarity principles by allowing corporate interests to override national environmental regulations through "barrier removal" clauses.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the importance of Japan addressing regulatory barriers to trade as a precondition for launching negotiations on an EU-Japan trade agreement, emphasizing the need to foster closer economic integration between the two partners. It highlighted the commitment from the 20th EU-Japan Summit in May 2011 to initiate discussions defining the scope and ambition of potential negotiations, supported by assessments from the Scoping Group and prior consultations, including a 2009 Copenhagen Economics report and a 2011 Commission public consultation. The resolution stressed that the Council should not authorize negotiations until Parliament formally stated its position on the proposed mandate, based on a report by the responsible committee, ensuring alignment with strategic priorities and addressing trade barriers effectively.

title: Exclusion of certain countries from trade preferences: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Annex I to Council Regulation (EC) No 1528/2007 as regards the exclusion of a number of countries from the list of regions or states which have concluded negotiations
background: The EU historically granted unilateral trade preferences to ACP countries under WTO waivers, replaced by interim Economic Partnership Agreements (EPAs) in 2007. A temporary Market Access Regulation maintained preferences for countries that initialled EPAs but delayed ratification, prompting a Commission proposal to end this arrangement. The Parliament will discuss amending trade preferences for non-ratifying ACP states.

stances.stance:
EPP rejects indefinite extensions of temporary trade preferences as fundamentally unfair to non-ACP developing nations.  
EPP opposes maintaining special status for ACP countries refusing to finalize economic partnership agreements.  
EPP insists on terminating outdated frameworks inconsistent with WTO rules and equitable global trade principles.  
EPP demands immediate cessation of transitional measures that undermine negotiation incentives for compliant partners.  
EPP calls for strict adherence to procedural timelines to prevent further distortions in EU trade policy.

GREEN_EFA strongly sanctions the issue’s emphasis on institutional transparency and procedural rigor, aligning perfectly with their commitment to equitable trade frameworks that prioritize developmental outcomes.  
GREEN_EFA proposes enhancing Article 3 to mandate periodic assessments of trade exclusion impacts on poverty reduction, ensuring alignment with the EU’s development cooperation principles.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s call for parliamentary re-engagement, which effectively advances their priority of safeguarding democratic oversight in trade policy decisions.  
GREEN_EFA approves the rejection of coercive trade tactics, urging stricter safeguards to protect regional integration projects in Africa from destabilizing market access restrictions.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the need to condition any exclusion measures on verifiable progress toward Sustainable Development Goals, reinforcing the issue’s developmental coherence.

ALDE strongly sanctions the compromise proposal's balanced approach in setting a WTO-aligned deadline while granting transitional flexibility for ACP countries.  
ALDE approves the two-year extension period as strategically enabling intensified outreach to civil society and legislators in partner states to secure durable agreements.  
ALDE proposes organizing public seminars with ACP media and NGOs to amplify transparency, directly implementing Rinaldi's Horsens Assembly recommendation for inclusive dialogue.  
ALDE emphasizes that transmitting Parliament's position to national legislatures aligns perfectly with their commitment to multilevel governance in trade policymaking.  
ALDE applauds the issue's institutional coherence, advancing their manifesto priority for WTO compliance paired with development-sensitive implementation timelines.

SD strongly advocates extending the negotiation deadline to 2016, aligning with their commitment to equitable development partnerships and ensuring ACP countries have sufficient time for EPA ratification without undue pressure.  
SD endorses the issue’s balance between WTO compliance and developmental fairness, preventing discriminatory treatment of ACP nations while upholding international trade obligations.  
SD emphasizes the necessity of the 2016 deadline as a firm compromise, providing legal clarity for EU and ACP businesses and avoiding indefinite non-compliance with global trade rules.  
SD proposes reinforcing technical assistance during the extension period to address regional integration challenges, particularly in SADC, ensuring EPAs foster sustainable economic cohesion.  
SD applauds the alignment of this timeline with broader EU-Africa cooperation goals, including the Cotonou Agreement review, as a strategic advancement of shared development priorities.

ECR absolutely disputes the exclusion framework as coercive trade conditionality that penalizes developing nations' policy autonomy.  
ECR rejects the issue's linkage of market access to EPA compliance, deeming it incompatible with their principles of voluntary partnership and differentiated development paths.  
ECR condemns the punitive withdrawal mechanism for non-signatory states, arguing it violates their core doctrine of trade sovereignty and equitable North-South relations.  
ECR disputes the fairness rationale, asserting the proposal institutionalizes asymmetry by leveraging EU market power against weaker economies.  
ECR highlights contradictions with subsidiarity principles, noting the issue centralizes trade policy decisions contrary to their advocacy for national flexibility.

GUE/NGL supports the issue’s emphasis on institutional cooperation but advises amending Annex I to explicitly prohibit coercive tactics like export tax abolition demands, referencing Namibia’s legitimate industrial policy as a model.  
GUE/NGL urges the Commission to withdraw clauses isolating ACP states, aligning with Article 294(2) procedural fairness and Development Committee objections to unilateral market-access threats.  
GUE/NGL proposes inserting binding timelines for EPA renegotiations to prevent punitive exclusion of Kenya and other East African partners, ensuring parity in EU-ACP trade relations.  
GUE/NGL highlights the issue’s procedural safeguards but insists on adding a clause to protect DFQF access for vulnerable sectors, citing Namibia’s EUR 60 million beef export risk as a non-negotiable development priority.  
GUE/NGL advises conditioning any trade preference exclusions on independent human rights and economic impact assessments, consistent with Rule 55 transparency requirements.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2011 proposal (COM(2011)0598) concerning the common commercial policy under Article 207(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, emphasizing alignment with procedural and legal frameworks, including Article 294(2) and Rule 55 of its Rules of Procedure. It endorsed the Committee on International Trade’s report (A7-0207/2012) and considered the Committee on Development’s opinion, formally adopting its first-reading stance while urging the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing significant amendments or alternative texts. The resolution underscored the need to uphold institutional cooperation by instructing its President to transmit Parliament’s position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring transparency and adherence to legislative processes governing EU trade policy.

title: Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement between the EU and its Member States, Australia, Canada, Japan, the Republic of Korea, Mexico, Morocco, New Zealand, Singapore, Switzerland and the USA: RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, Australia, Canada, Japan, the Republic of Korea, the United Mexican States, the Kingdom of Morocco, New Zealand, the Republic of Singapore, the Swiss Confederation and the United States of America
background: The EU and 11 trading partners negotiated ACTA to strengthen intellectual property enforcement amid rising counterfeit trade and online piracy. Confidential negotiations and public concerns over civil liberties prompted a European Commission request for a European Court of Justice compatibility review. The Parliament will discuss the agreement’s ratification, addressing intellectual property standards, digital enforcement measures, and international trade cooperation.

stances.stance:
EPP totally rejects with the issue's rejection of ACTA, emphasizing its necessity to safeguard intellectual property rights and combat €150 billion in annual counterfeit-related losses.  
EPP rejects the premature vote against ACTA, asserting that dismissing it without the European Court of Justice's legal opinion undermines procedural rigor and fails to address patent safety and job protection.  
EPP opposes the issue's oversight of ACTA's alignment with existing EU IP laws, arguing it weakens Europe's ability to demand anti-counterfeiting measures from non-participating nations like China.  
 While most EPP members opposed the issue, internal dissent emerged regarding digital freedoms, with figures like Paweł Zalewski citing imbalances between creator rights and internet user protections.  
EPP highlights the issue's failure to acknowledge ACTA's role in preventing counterfeit medicines and dangerous goods, directly contradicting their consumer safety priorities.

EFD rejects the ACTA agreement as fundamentally incompatible with safeguarding digital freedoms and democratic accountability.  
EFD opposes the criminalization provisions in Article 23, warning they enable suppression of dissent akin to the Julian Assange case.  
EFD condemns the exclusion of 95% of counterfeit-exporting nations like China, rendering the agreement ineffective against actual trade violations.  
EFD highlights the undemocratic negotiation process, which bypassed public consultation and eroded trust in EU institutions.  
EFD asserts that combating counterfeiting requires port inspections and global engagement rather than internet restrictions threatening privacy rights.

GREEN_EFA opposes fundamentally the agreement's failure to safeguard digital freedoms, directly conflicting with their mandate to protect freedom of expression and privacy as outlined in the issue’s Article 4.  
GREEN_EFA rejects the enforcement model privatizing internet oversight, inconsistent with their principle against corporate surveillance regimes cited in the issue’s "free and open internet" clause.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the exclusion of developing economies in standard-setting, contradicting their advocacy for equitable global health access referenced in the issue’s OECD counterfeiting data context.  
GREEN_EFA disputes the agreement’s legal ambiguity on generics, which the issue identifies as irreconcilable with EU public health priorities under intellectual property laws.  
GREEN_EFA denounces the opaque negotiation process, aligning with the issue’s demand for transparent impact assessments to prevent undemocratic policymaking.

ALDE rejects the ACTA agreement as fundamentally incompatible with its principles of safeguarding digital freedoms and transparent policymaking.  
ALDE opposes the issue's failure to address critical privacy concerns, particularly regarding extrajudicial internet surveillance provisions that conflict with EU data protection standards.  
ALDE highlights the agreement's exclusion of major counterfeit producers like China and India as rendering it economically ineffective, contradicting ALDE's demand for evidence-based trade solutions.  
ALDE condemns the closed negotiation process as antithetical to its commitment to participatory democracy, noting 2.8 million citizen petitions against ACTA.  
ALDE insists on sector-specific IP enforcement frameworks, rejecting the issue's broad approach that conflates physical counterfeiting with digital content governance.

SD rejects ACTA's fundamental premise of conflating physical counterfeiting with digital sharing, directly conflicting with SD's commitment to safeguarding open internet ecosystems.  
SD opposes the agreement's Article 27 provisions enabling private surveillance of users, violating SD's non-negotiable stance on data protection and presumption of innocence.  
SD condemns ACTA's exclusion of China and other major counterfeit producers as structurally flawed, rendering it ineffective for its stated purpose while risking disproportionate EU citizen monitoring.  
SD highlights ACTA's incompatibility with ongoing EU copyright reforms, demanding internal legislative clarity before binding international commitments per SD's governance principles.  
SD aligns with mass public protests against ACTA's procedural opacity, upholding civil society's role in shaping digital policy as central to SD's democratic mandate.

GUE_NGL rejects ACTA as an undemocratic threat to digital freedoms and privacy rights, fully conflicting with their commitment to an open internet.  
GUE_NGL opposes the agreement's secretive negotiation process that bypassed democratic scrutiny, overlooking critical public demands for transparency.  
GUE_NGL condemns ACTA's alignment with corporate monopolies over knowledge-sharing, directly contradicting their vision of collective information access.  
GUE_NGL denounces the Commission's contempt for mass protests against ACTA, which demonstrated irreconcilable differences with grassroots democratic movements.  
GUE_NGL asserts that ACTA's IP enforcement model perpetuates capitalist control over digital spaces, violating principles of equitable knowledge distribution.

resolution: The European Parliament raised objections to the Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement (ACTA) with non-EU countries, declining consent for its conclusion due to concerns over insufficient safeguards for fundamental rights, including freedom of expression and privacy, and potential conflicts with EU intellectual property (IP) laws. It emphasized that existing EU legislation on copyright in the information society is already advanced and aligned with international standards, while noting the economic significance of IP protection, citing OECD estimates of €150 billion annual losses from global counterfeiting and piracy. The resolution highlighted a rise in customs seizures of suspected IP-infringing goods from 43,500 cases in 2009 to nearly 80,000 in 2010 but acknowledged gaps in data on IP violations. It stressed the need for balanced measures that protect IP rights without undermining a free and open internet, asserting that property rights and information freedom are compatible both online and offline. The Parliament called for transparent, independent impact assessments of future legislative proposals and instructed its leadership to notify the Council and relevant international partners of its rejection of the agreement.

title: Bilateral safeguard clause in the EU-Korea free trade agreement: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council implementing the bilateral safeguard clause of the EU-Korea Free Trade Agreement
background: The EU-Korea Free Trade Agreement established a bilateral safeguard mechanism, with the Treaty of Lisbon granting the European Parliament co-legislative authority over trade agreements. The Council moved to provisionally apply the FTA. The Parliament will discuss implementing the agreement's safeguard clause under its new institutional role and procedural requirements.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly upholds the implementation of Parliament's right to initiate safeguard investigations, aligning with their commitment to institutional accountability under the Lisbon Treaty.  
EPP strongly endorses the inclusion of duty drawback provisions in the safeguard clause and urges the Council to expedite approval to ensure balanced market access.  
EPP proposes enhanced monitoring of Korea’s CO2 regulations for vehicles, advocating for Commission-led negotiations to prevent non-tariff barriers to EU automotive exports.  
EPP approves the agreement’s economic scope but suggests evaluating EU-wide safeguard mechanisms to complement regional measures, ensuring alignment with internal market principles.   
EPP applauds the integration of social and environmental standards in trade policy, advancing their 2023 priority of linking competitiveness with sustainable development.

EFD supports the adoption of the EU-Korea FTA as strategically urgent to preempt US-Korea ratification, aligning with economic growth priorities.  
EFD advises amending the agreement to mandate independent EU labor experts’ unfettered access to Kaesong Industrial Complex facilities, specifying exclusion of KIC products if such monitoring is obstructed.  
EFD highlights concerns about systemic corruption in Korea, urging the issue to integrate enhanced due diligence protocols for trade partner governance standards.  
EFD endorses transparency mechanisms in the agreement but cautions that accelerated timelines must not dilute human rights safeguards against forced labor risks.  
EFD proposes reinforcing Article 207(2) procedures with biannual parliamentary reviews on Korea’s compliance with anticorruption and labor commitments.

ALDE strongly endorses the swift ratification of the EU-Korea FTA while emphasizing the necessity of robust safeguard clauses to address sectoral imbalances, aligning with ALDE's commitment to fair trade frameworks.  
ALDE proposes enhancing the duty drawback monitoring mechanism to prevent third-country exploitation, ensuring tariff reductions benefit EU-Korean trade reciprocity as envisioned in Article 4.  
ALDE insists on integrating a regional safeguard clause to accommodate diverse economic impacts across Member States, strengthening the issue’s flexibility without opposing its core structure.  
ALDE demands reinforced parliamentary oversight in comitology procedures under Article 9, advocating for an advisory veto right to maintain institutional balance post-Lisbon Treaty.  
ALDE underscores the imperative to delay provisional application until parliamentary consent, aligning with Treaty obligations and preventing premature implementation risks.

SD strongly accepts the safeguard regulation's emphasis on institutional accountability, particularly the requirement for Commission re-engagement with Parliament on substantive amendments, aligning with SD's commitment to post-Lisbon treaty power balances.  

SD proposes enhancing Article 6 monitoring mechanisms to explicitly include duty drawback impacts on EU manufacturers, ensuring legally binding market distortion assessments rather than declaratory measures.  

SD approves the regional safeguard clause framework but urges concrete implementation protocols to protect vulnerable sectors in specific Member States, reflecting SD's priority for equitable internal market protections.  

SD emphasizes strict adherence to provisional application timelines only after Parliamentary approval of the full package, requiring deletion of ambiguous "most likely" phrasing in Annex 2 to prevent premature implementation.  

SD advocates expanding the Domestic Advisory Groups' mandate to systematically review compliance with ILO Core Conventions, particularly addressing South Korea's Article 314 penal code conflicts with workers' right to strike.

ECR supports the issue’s procedural safeguards for parliamentary oversight, aligning with institutional accountability priorities in trade agreements.  
ECR advises amending Article 2 to define "substantial amendments" with quantitative thresholds (e.g., >10% tariff adjustments) to clarify re-engagement triggers.  
ECR proposes adding a 15-day consultation window in Article 4 for national parliaments to review safeguard measures before Commission adoption.  
ECR recommends reinforcing Annex I’s injury assessment criteria with sector-specific employment impact metrics to better reflect domestic industry needs.  
 While endorsing transparency goals, ECR stresses stricter timelines for Commission-Parliament notifications to prevent procedural delays.

GUE_NGL rejects the safeguard implementation framework for failing to mandate unanimous Council ratification, creating undemocratic enforcement gaps inconsistent with sovereignty principles.  
GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the origin rules' treatment of duty drawbacks, which neglect trade unions' documented concerns about Asian production chain vulnerabilities.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue's crisis-era safeguards as structurally inadequate, arguing they prioritize corporate trade flows over worker protections during financial instability.  
GUE_NGL disputes the "serious case" activation thresholds as unenforceably vague, contradicting their demand for quantifiable injury metrics aligned with SME realities.  
GUE_NGL highlights the exclusion of civil society monitoring mechanisms, entirely conflicting with their manifesto commitment to participatory trade governance.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position by adopting the Commission’s legislative proposal COM(2010)0049 at first reading, which pertains to trade-related matters under Article 207(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. The resolution emphasized the need for the Commission to re-engage Parliament if it seeks to introduce substantial amendments or replace the proposal, ensuring legislative transparency and institutional accountability. Additionally, Parliament instructed its President to formally communicate its adopted position to the Council, the Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing inter-institutional dialogue and adherence to procedural frameworks outlined in its Rules of Procedure and treaty obligations.

title: Financing instrument for cooperation with industrialised countries: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1934/2006 establishing a financing instrument for cooperation with industrialised and other high-income countries and territories
background: The European Commission’s 2006 regulation established a financing instrument for cooperation with industrialised countries, with subsequent Treaty of Lisbon reforms altering institutional procedures and a 2008 European Court of Justice ruling requiring adjustments. A 2009 mid-term review assessed operational alignment. The Parliament will discuss amendments to the regulation addressing treaty compliance, expanded cooperation scope, and SALW inclusion.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly promotes the reinforced parliamentary oversight through Articles 14a-14c, aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to institutional balance under the Lisbon Treaty.  
EPP approves the financial equilibrium mechanism between development cooperation and industrial country instruments, proposing enhanced reporting requirements in Article 7 to ensure fund complementarity.  
EPP fundamentally endorses support for ACP countries' agricultural competitiveness, urging amendment of Annex II to include post-2013 evaluation mechanisms for banana sector adaptations.  
EPP emphasizes democracy promotion as central to all instruments, suggesting revised Article 3 wording to prioritize grassroots civil society capacity-building in authoritarian regimes.  
EPP welcomes flexibility provisions while proposing simplified application processes in Article 9 to better accommodate small NGOs implementing local democratic initiatives.

EFD supports the reinforced parliamentary oversight in Articles 14a-14c but advises amending Annex A to explicitly exclude regimes with documented military aggression from funding eligibility.  
EFD expresses concern over expanding cooperation to 46 additional countries without proportional accountability safeguards, urging amendment of Article 3 to require human rights impact assessments for all beneficiaries.  
EFD partially agrees transparency mechanisms in Article 4 but proposes inserting a recital mandating quarterly public expenditure reports accessible to national parliaments.  
EFD advises reallocating 15% of the instrument's budget to domestic youth employment initiatives in line with austerity principles, modifying Article 9's financial provisions accordingly.  
EFD requests Article 13 revisions to cap administrative costs at 5% of total allocations, citing taxpayer burden concerns raised during economic stagnation.

GREEN_EFA strongly sanctions the reinforced parliamentary oversight mechanisms in Articles 14a-14c, which align with their commitment to democratic accountability in development spending.  
GREEN_EFA approves the issue’s emphasis on transparency and ODA compliance, directly advancing their priority to eradicate poverty through rigorously monitored aid allocation.  
GREEN_EFA endorses the institutional balance provisions requiring Commission re-engagement with Parliament, reflecting their manifesto demand for equitable decision-making in EU external action.  
GREEN_EFA proposes enhancing Article 3’s implementation guidelines by integrating comparative analysis of flexible financing models, such as those referenced in US democratization programs, to optimize impact.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s coherence with sustainable development principles, particularly its implicit support for reorienting agricultural models toward local self-sufficiency and environmental protection.

ALDE strongly endorses the reinforced parliamentary oversight mechanisms in Articles 14a-14c, aligning with Annemie Neyts-Uyttebroeck's emphasis on institutional balance and expanded legislative scrutiny under Lisbon Treaty reforms.  
ALDE approves the issue’s coherence with development policy objectives, particularly Louis Michel’s focus on prioritizing aid to ACP countries impacted by trade shifts, ensuring alignment with sustainable development goals.  
ALDE proposes enhancing transparency by formally integrating NGO participation into the Instrument for Stability’s implementation protocols, reflecting Annemie Neyts-Uyttebroeck’s call for broader civil society engagement in crisis response.  
ALDE applauds the accountability measures in amended Articles 7 and 9 as advancing their manifesto commitment to rigorous budgetary oversight and anti-fraud safeguards.  
ALDE suggests exploring modalities to progressively align European Development Fund management with the EU budget framework, echoing Louis Michel’s advocacy for streamlined financial governance without opposing current provisions.

SD strongly sanctions the reinforcement of parliamentary oversight through Articles 14a-14c, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to institutional balance and scrutiny post-Lisbon Treaty.  
SD approves the enhanced transparency mechanisms in Articles 3 and 7, emphasizing that annual reporting on project eligibility must prioritize ODA alignment to advance development coherence.  
SD proposes augmenting the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights budget to fund a cross-party foundation model, enhancing flexibility for grassroots democratic movements without diverting aid from poverty eradication.  
SD underscores the necessity of increasing human rights expertise within the External Action Service to strengthen delegated act implementation, ensuring strategic programming aligns with development priorities.  
SD advocates for extended multiannual financing for ACP Banana Accompanying Measures to address tariff inequities, ensuring competitiveness while maintaining solidarity with historical trade partners.

GUE/NGL supports the amendments reinforcing parliamentary oversight of delegated acts in Articles 14a-14c, aligning with demands for democratic accountability in foreign policy instruments.  
GUE/NGL advises revising Article 3 to explicitly prohibit funding allocations that prioritize transnational corporations over small producers, citing concerns about banana tariff agreements devastating ACP economies.  
GUE/NGL proposes adding transparency clauses to Article 7 requiring impact assessments on how stability funds affect local populations, addressing critiques of undemocratic interventionism.  
GUE/NGL stresses the need to amend Article 9's development policy coherence provisions to exclude neoliberal conditionalities exacerbating poverty through austerity measures.  
 GUE/NGL questions the effectiveness of democracy promotion funding without first addressing EU internal democratic deficits highlighted in abstention rates and media influence.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a Commission proposal concerning the multiannual financial framework for 2007-2013, affirming compatibility while emphasizing that annual appropriations for 2010-2013 remain subject to the budgetary authority’s decisions during annual budget procedures. It introduced specific amendments to Articles 3, 4, 5, 7, 9, 13, and 14 of the proposal, including revisions to provisions on delegated powers, transparency, and accountability mechanisms, and inserted new Articles 14a-14c to reinforce parliamentary oversight over delegated acts. These amendments aimed to clarify procedures for the adoption, revocation, and objection to delegated acts, ensuring the European Parliament’s role in scrutinizing and challenging such measures. The resolution stressed the need for institutional balance, requiring the Commission to re-engage Parliament if substantial changes to the proposal occur, and underscored alignment with the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, particularly regarding trade and development policy coherence.

title: Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) No …/... of 28.8.2013 establishing Annex III to Regulation (EU) No 978/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council applying a scheme of generalised tariff preferences: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) No .../... of 28 August 2013 establishing Annex III to Regulation (EU) No 978/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council applying a scheme of generalised tariff preferences (C(2013)05541)
background: The European Commission adopted a delegated regulation in August 2013 adding ten countries to the EU's GSP+ scheme, which grants trade preferences conditional on adherence to international conventions on human rights, labor, and environmental standards. The Parliament will discuss the procedural approach to listing beneficiary countries under the GSP+ framework.

stances.stance:
EPP rejects the bundled approval mechanism as totally condemning with its principle of rigorous trade policy oversight.  
EPP opposes the single delegated act approach for failing to address country-specific governance risks highlighted in Resolution 978/2012.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of EPP's trade conditionality framework by preventing granular human rights assessments per beneficiary state.  
 While some EPP members pragmatically accept the Commission's method, the official position aligns with Saïfi's critique of eroded parliamentary scrutiny capacities.  
EPP demands separate evaluation processes to maintain coherence with its 2013 manifesto commitment to "trade justice through individualized partnership monitoring."

GREEN_EFA strongly agrees the issue's rejection of bundled country assessments, aligning with their demand for rigorous human rights scrutiny in trade agreements.  
GREEN_EFA proposes enhancing Annex III evaluations by requiring country-specific monitoring mechanisms for high-risk states like Pakistan, ensuring compliance with anti-violence conventions.  
GREEN_EFA approves the call to separate delegated acts, preventing opaque inclusions such as Burma/Myanmar and upholding Parliament’s post-Lisbon oversight role.  
GREEN_EFA urges stricter timelines for Commission compliance reports, addressing concerns about delayed access to critical human rights assessments.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s alignment with their manifesto priority to condition trade preferences on verifiable democratic governance reforms.

ALDE rejects the Commission’s bundled approach to GSP+ beneficiaries as firmly conflicting with their insistence on transparent legislative scrutiny and country-specific accountability.  
ALDE opposes the procedural failure to share critical compliance assessments before parliamentary review, undermining their principle of informed democratic oversight in trade policy.  
ALDE highlights the Commission’s inadequate evaluations of Pakistan and Armenia, which overlook critical human rights and governance deficiencies inconsistent with ALDE’s strict conditionality standards.  
ALDE demands separate delegated acts for each country to align with their commitment to granular accountability, rejecting collective approval as a breach of Regulation (EU) No 978/2012’s intent.  
ALDE insists the issue’s call for rigorous monitoring mechanisms is vital, as the current regulation lacks enforceable safeguards against backsliding on international conventions.

SD rejects the Commission’s bundled approach to GSP+ eligibility, as it fundamentally disapproves with SD’s principle of rigorous legislative scrutiny and individual country accountability under Regulation (EU) No 978/2012.  
SD opposes the delegated act’s failure to address concealed monitoring reports on Pakistan’s human rights violations, directly contradicting SD’s demand for transparent pre-assessment disclosure.  
SD highlights the issue’s critical oversight gap regarding immediate sanctions for labor rights violations, inconsistent with SD’s 2023 manifesto commitment to enforceable trade conditionality.  
SD condemns the Commission’s improvisation of a "scorecard system" without parliamentary consultation, overlooking SD’s requirement for clear evaluation metrics and multilateral oversight mechanisms.  
SD demands separate delegated acts per applicant country to ensure compliance with core conventions, as the current package risks transforming GSP+ into an unmonitored economic transaction rather than a rights-based development tool.

ECR completely opposes the inclusion of Pakistan in the GSP+ scheme given its documented regression on human rights and labor standards despite previous textile tariff concessions.  
ECR rejects the Commission's bundled country approach as geopolitically incoherent, grouping nations with divergent governance records like Armenia and Pakistan under a single non-negotiable framework.  
This regulation conflicts with ECR's principle of rigorous conditionality by failing to mandate individualized compliance reports for each beneficiary state prior to approval.  
The proposal overlooks critical damage to EU textile producers from previous unilateral concessions to Pakistan that yielded no democratic reforms.  
ECR demands immediate suspension of preferences for countries violating core conventions, citing Ecuador's environmental deregulation and Georgia's union-busting practices as unresolved issues.

GUE_NGL supports the issue’s demand for separate delegated acts per country to enable rigorous scrutiny of GSP+ compliance, as collective approval undermines democratic oversight.  
GUE_NGL advises the Commission to establish transparent criteria for "serious failure" in convention implementation, ensuring consistent enforcement beyond extreme cases like Sri Lanka.  
GUE_NGL proposes making GSP+ scorecards public to facilitate civil society input and align with transparency mandates under Regulation (EU) No 978/2012.
