ALDE affirms the issue’s historic significance in demonstrating EU institutional coherence, directly advancing ALDE's advocacy for efficient decision-making in complex international negotiations.

SD strongly endorses the repeal of Regulation (EC) No 1964/2005 as a critical step toward fulfilling the EU’s multilateral trade obligations under the Geneva Agreement, aligning with SD’s commitment to equitable global economic integration.  
SD applauds the €190 million Banana Accompanying Measures as essential to safeguarding ACP producers’ livelihoods, directly advancing SD’s priority of protecting vulnerable economies from asymmetric market pressures.  
SD proposes enhancing competition law enforcement mechanisms to prevent multinational monopolistic practices, ensuring the issue’s tariff reductions do not inadvertently harm small-scale producers or consumers.  
SD urges the Commission to formalize the 2020 impact assessment as a binding requirement to evaluate long-term effects on ACP nations and outermost regions, reinforcing transparency in trade policy outcomes.  
SD emphasizes integrating fair trade certification incentives into the agreement’s implementation to elevate labor and environmental standards, reflecting SD’s manifesto goals for ethical consumption.

GUE_NGL firmly doubts the repeal of Regulation 1964/2005 as it sacrifices ACP and EU outermost regions' small producers to multinational corporate interests, directly contradicting their anti-neoliberal trade principles.  
GUE_NGL rejects the €190 million compensation package as grossly inadequate to prevent the destruction of traditional banana farming communities, violating their commitment to economic justice.  
GUE_NGL condemns the agreement's alignment with WTO priorities over environmental and worker protections, highlighting its incompatibility with their manifesto's demand for trade policy democratization.  
GUE_NGL denounces the exclusion of ACP producers from negotiations as neo-colonial practice, directly opposing their decolonial trade solidarity principles.  
GUE_NGL declares the issue's market liberalization framework incompatible with their vision of food sovereignty, demanding complete rejection rather than technical adjustments.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the adoption of a resolution endorsing the Agreement on Trade in Bananas, which resolves a longstanding WTO dispute through three key components: a schedule of tariff reductions for most-favoured nation (MFN) banana exporters, a framework for addressing "tropical products" and "preference erosion" in WTO negotiations, and a €190 million financial package (Banana Accompanying Measures) to support ACP banana exporters. The resolution supports abolishing the current EU MFN tariff rate of €176 per tonne for bananas by repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 1964/2005, aligning with commitments under the Geneva Agreement. It welcomes the conclusion of the WTO dispute as politically and commercially significant, despite not fully reconciling all parties' interests, and affirms that the agreement will finalize EU market access commitments for bananas within the Doha Round agricultural negotiations. The Parliament endorsed the Commission’s proposal at first reading, urging the Commission to re-engage Parliament if substantial amendments arise, and emphasized integrating the outcomes into broader multilateral trade frameworks.

title: Protection against dumped and subsidised imports from countries not members of the EU: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 1225/2009 on protection against dumped imports from countries not members of the European Community and Council Regulation (EC) No 597/2009 on protection against subsidised imports from countries not members of the European Community
background: The EU's existing trade defense regulations (1225/2009 and 597/2009) faced challenges from evolving global trade practices, increased non-EU subsidized imports, and high-profile cases like Chinese solar panels (2013). The Commission proposed modernization (COM(2013)0192) to address enforcement gaps and WTO compliance. The Parliament will discuss amendments to strengthen protections against dumped and subsidized imports while balancing market openness and EU industry interests.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly approves the modernization of trade defense instruments as essential for protecting EU industries from distorted competition, particularly endorsing measures against environmental and social dumping practices.  
EPP approves the compromise package's SME facilitation measures, proposing accelerated investigation timelines to ensure smaller enterprises can effectively utilize anti-dumping tools.  
EPP emphasizes the necessity of suspending the lesser duty rule in cases of raw material cost distortions, urging its judicious application to address paradigm shifts while preventing overreach.  
EPP advocates for pragmatic transitional arrangements regarding the shipping clause to maintain legal certainty for businesses, aligning with the need for balanced implementation.  
EPP urges swift Council action to finalize reforms before the legislative term ends, highlighting alignment with the party's 2023 competitiveness agenda for strategic autonomy.

GREEN_EFA fully approves the integration of international social and environmental standards into anti-dumping measures, perfectly aligning with their commitment to sustainable and equitable trade practices.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s critical role in preventing divisive external pressures like those seen in the Chinese photovoltaic case, ensuring unified EU industrial defense strategies.  
GREEN_EFA applauds enhanced SME access to trade defense mechanisms as a vital step toward balancing global market competitiveness with fair economic participation.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the mandate for parliamentary oversight, reinforcing democratic accountability in trade policy as a cornerstone of their governance principles.  
GREEN_EFA fully supports the issue’s framework for addressing subsidy-driven market distortions, recognizing its alignment with climate-conscious industrial policy goals.

ALDE strongly upholds the modernization of trade defense instruments as essential to protecting European industries from unfair competition, aligning with their commitment to assertive yet rules-based globalization.  
ALDE applauds the issue’s emphasis on institutional empowerment to overcome fragmented national interests, ensuring swift and unified EU action against market distortions like solar panel dumping.  
ALDE proposes strengthening tariff calibration in future measures to match the dissuasive impact seen in third-country systems, referencing the solar sector’s 64% EU vs. 249% US duty disparity as an enhancement opportunity.  
ALDE endorses the cultural shift framing trade defense as a rule-enforcement mechanism rather than protectionism, vital for safeguarding SMEs and maintaining fair global competition.  
ALDE emphasizes the need for coherence between trade policy and financial institutions’ practices, such as halting BEI funding for subsidized foreign competitors, to reinforce defensive measures.

SD strongly accepts the modernization of trade defense instruments to protect EU industry from unfair dumping practices, aligning perfectly with SD's longstanding commitment to safeguarding SMEs and high-value industrial jobs.  
SD strongly endorses the accelerated investigation timelines and Commission initiative powers, which effectively advance SD's priority of responsive trade policy enforcement against market-distorting subsidies.  
SD strongly accepts maintaining stringent Union interest assessments while proposing enhanced safeguards to prevent disproportionate weighting of importer interests over producer protections in anti-dumping cases.  
SD strongly approves the integration of international labor and environmental standards into injury calculations, advancing SD's manifesto goals for fair global competition.  
SD strongly advocates preserving the INTA Committee's improvements to the shipping clause provisions as critical for defending strategic European industries against predatory pricing.

ECR rejects the proposal's structural failure to enforce member state compliance mechanisms, absolutely condemning with their demand for binding national trade defense implementation.  
ECR opposes the unresolved offshore zone loopholes as inconsistent with their requirement for territorial accountability in anti-dumping cases.  
ECR condemns the lack of WTO-aligned subsidy countermeasures, overlooking critical aspects of asymmetric competition from state-supported third-country exporters.  
ECR disputes the Council's procedural delays embedded in the issue, mirroring Muscardini's critique of institutional inertia blocking economic recovery.  
ECR absolutely condemns with the proposal's tolerance for non-transparent corporate registrations, perpetuating unfair trade practices against EU manufacturers.

GUE_NGL rejects the proposal's failure to prohibit using trade instruments to coerce market access from developing nations, directly conflicting with their 2010 stance on resource sovereignty.  
GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the omission of binding measures against social/environmental dumping, which the issue overlooks despite UN Charter obligations for equitable cooperation.  
GUE_NGL condemns the regulation’s potential to institutionalize low raw material pricing, perpetuating wage suppression and poverty in violation of decent work principles.  
GUE_NGL disputes the proposal’s compatibility with Article 3 of the UN Charter, as it prioritizes commercial interests over solving economic inequalities through multilateralism.  
GUE_NGL declares the text illegitimate without Amendment 83’s explicit integration of environmental and labor safeguards, rendering it inconsistent with their anti-dumping framework.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2013 proposal concerning international trade, adopting its first-reading stance to advance legislative procedures under Article 207(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. It emphasized the need for the Commission to re-engage Parliament if substantial amendments or replacements to the original proposal (COM(2013)0192) are contemplated, ensuring parliamentary oversight. The resolution further directed the Parliament’s President to formally communicate its adopted position to the Council, the Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing procedural transparency and institutional alignment in the EU’s trade policy framework.

title: Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the EC and Israel on Conformity Assessment and Acceptance of Industrial Products (CAA): RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Euro Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the State of Israel, of the other part, on Conformity Assessment and Acceptance of Industrial Products (CAA)
background: The EU and Israel’s Euro-Mediterranean Association Agreement (2000) established trade frameworks, with a 2010-negotiated Protocol on Conformity Assessment and Acceptance of Industrial Products (CAA) aiming to reduce technical barriers. The EU maintains non-recognition of Israeli jurisdiction in territories occupied since 1967. The Parliament will discuss concluding the CAA Protocol under the existing agreement.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly approves the ACAA protocol as a vital step in eliminating technical trade barriers, aligning with their commitment to deepening Euro-Mediterranean economic cooperation through regulatory alignment.  
EPP applauds the explicit exclusion of products from occupied territories under the protocol’s scope, emphasizing its consistency with EU positions on territorial applicability and Israel’s 1967 borders.  
EPP highlights the agreement’s consumer benefits, particularly accelerated access to high-quality generic pharmaceuticals for EU patients, which aligns with public health priorities and single-market efficiency goals.  
EPP proposes enhanced monitoring mechanisms to ensure territorial compliance, suggesting regular Commission reporting to maintain transparency without opposing the agreement’s core objectives.  
EPP underscores the importance of maintaining balanced EU-Israel relations, viewing the protocol as a technical instrument that strengthens shared standards while preserving the EU’s role as a neutral mediator in broader regional disputes.

EFD strongly endorses the protocol's facilitation of pharmaceutical trade, aligning with their commitment to practical EU-Israel cooperation that benefits European patients through cost-effective medical access.  
EFD approves the issue’s economic rationale, emphasizing Italy’s projected €1 billion annual savings in healthcare costs as a model of EU-Israel technical synergy.  
EFD highlights the need to streamline parliamentary procedures to avoid undue delays, proposing enhanced monitoring of implementation timelines to ensure democratic efficiency.  
EFD commends the exclusion of occupied territories from the agreement’s scope, reinforcing their stance on legally precise international frameworks.  
EFD urges continued prioritization of sector-specific trade agreements that bypass political disputes, citing Israel’s pharmaceutical innovation as a benchmark for EU competitiveness.

GREEN_EFA rejects the protocol as it fundamentally disputes with their commitment to upholding international law and human rights in Palestinian territories.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the agreement for failing to guarantee traceability of products from Israeli settlements, directly contradicting EU diplomatic reports on origin verification.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the protocol’s political timing, arguing it rewards Netanyahu’s expansion of illegal settlements despite EU condemnation of such policies.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s inconsistency with the EU’s 2009 suspension of economic relations upgrades, undermining coherence in Middle East policy.  
GREEN_EFA asserts the agreement overlooks worsening Palestinian rights violations, prioritizing trade over accountability for occupation practices.

SD rejects the protocol as fundamentally incompatible with EU human rights obligations, citing Israel’s systemic violations of Palestinian rights through land seizures and movement restrictions.  
SD opposes extending market privileges to Israeli exporters while settlements in occupied territories persist, creating an unjust economic advantage rooted in illegal occupation.  
SD condemns the agreement’s failure to enforce territorial exclusions, risking implicit recognition of Israeli sovereignty over occupied lands contrary to international law.  
SD highlights the contradiction between this trade upgrade and EU foreign policy positions, undermining cohesion with repeated condemnations of settlement expansion.  
SD demands suspension until Israel halts collective punishment in Gaza and dismantles settlements, aligning trade decisions with human rights conditionality.

ECR strongly upholds the protocol as a technical trade facilitation measure, aligning with their commitment to barrier-free commerce and mutual recognition of high regulatory standards.  
ECR approves the exclusion of settlement-produced goods under Commission assurances, emphasizing Israel's democratic governance and pharmaceutical sector's compliance with EU safety requirements.  
ECR highlights the agreement's economic rationale, noting its potential to reduce medication costs for European patients through streamlined certification of Israeli generics.  
ECR rejects conflation with geopolitical issues, urging adherence to trade merits alone as demonstrated in identical protocols with other Mediterranean partners.  
ECR proposes enhancing the Commission's implementation reports with quarterly progress metrics on territorial compliance verification to reinforce transparency.

GUE_NGL rejects the protocol as a de facto political endorsement of Israel’s systemic oppression of Palestinians, firmly disputeing with their commitment to anti-colonial solidarity and human rights.  
GUE_NGL opposes the agreement’s framing as "technical," highlighting its role in integrating Israel into the EU single market despite ongoing illegal settlements and Gaza’s humanitarian crisis.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue’s failure to address Israel’s blockade of Gaza, which directly contradicts EU principles on freedom of movement and access to essential medicines.  
GUE_NGL asserts that any economic cooperation with Israel legitimizes violations of international law, including the 2012 clarification’s inadequacy to prevent settlement-linked trade normalization.  
GUE_NGL demands unconditional rejection of the protocol, citing Israel’s violent interception of humanitarian aid ships as emblematic of policies incompatible with EU values.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its consent to the conclusion of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement with Israel on Conformity Assessment and Acceptance of Industrial Products (CAA), aimed at facilitating trade through mutual recognition of industrial product assessments. It emphasized the need for clarity on the territorial competence of Israeli authorities, following concerns addressed by Commissioner De Gucht’s July 2012 clarification that the protocol’s scope excludes Israeli settlements in occupied territories. The resolution called on the Commission to regularly report on the protocol’s implementation and instructed the Parliament’s President to communicate the decision to relevant EU and Israeli institutions. Key documents referenced include the draft Council decision (12428/2012) and the draft protocol (05212/2010), with committees on International Trade (INTA) and Foreign Affairs (AFET) overseeing procedural alignment under Treaty on the Functioning of the EU Articles 207 and 218.

title: State of play of the Doha development agenda: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the state of play of the Doha Development Agenda and preparations for the Ninth WTO Ministerial Conference
background: Initiated in 2001 to address trade imbalances and prioritize developing countries, the Doha Development Agenda faced prolonged negotiations, including a 2008 stalemate. With the Ninth WTO Ministerial Conference scheduled for December 2013 in Bali, the EU emphasized multilateral trade and WTO reform. The Parliament will discuss progress on the Doha Round and preparations for the Bali ministerial meeting.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly sanctions the urgent conclusion of the Doha Round at the Bali Ministerial Conference, particularly emphasizing trade facilitation measures that could boost global GDP through streamlined customs procedures. This aligns perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to multilateral trade liberalization and economic growth.  
EPP strongly endorses plurilateral agreements such as the Trade in Services Agreement (TiSA) and the revised Government Procurement Agreement, recognizing their potential to enhance competitiveness in both developed and developing nations while advancing the issue's goals of service sector liberalization.  
EPP proposes enhancing flexibility in implementation modalities to allow progressive adoption of Doha outcomes, particularly for SMEs, suggesting that not all elements need to be bound by a single undertaking approach while maintaining full commitment to the package's integrity.  
EPP strongly sanctions increased Aid for Trade funding and capacity-building programs for LDCs, urging restoration of 2011 funding levels to strengthen infrastructure development and integration into global value chains as outlined in the issue.  
EPP strongly advocates for strengthened WTO dispute settlement mechanisms and monitoring of compliance with tariff reduction commitments, particularly regarding agricultural subsidies, to ensure equitable participation of all member states in global trade.

GREEN_EFA rejects the issue's endorsement of plurilateral agreements like TiSA and GPA as firmly disputeing with their demand for strict multilateral WTO reform, which Franziska Keller explicitly denounced as undermining development priorities.  

GREEN_EFA opposes the proposal to differentiate among developing countries using "objective criteria" as inconsistent with their insistence on full, undiluted special treatment for LDCs in market access and services waiver implementation.  

GREEN_EFA condemns the issue's failure to mandate binding climate obligations in trade rules, overlooking critical aspects of environmental justice central to GREEN_EFA's platform, as highlighted in the debate's emphasis on climate change integration.  

GREEN_EFA rejects the limited ambition on cotton trade reforms and rules of origin adjustments, which the debate identified as non-negotiable for equitable LDC participation in global value chains.  

GREEN_EFA opposes the issue's silence on gender disparity mitigation in trade policy, directly contradicting their principle that trade systems must address structural inequalities as outlined by Keller.

ALDE strongly promotes the issue’s binding trade facilitation measures, which align perfectly with ALDE’s commitment to reducing bureaucratic barriers for SMEs and fostering equitable global trade growth.  
ALDE approves the emphasis on parliamentary oversight of WTO agreements, effectively advancing their manifesto goals for democratic accountability in multilateral trade governance.  
ALDE proposes organizing post-conference public dialogues with NGOs and businesses to enhance transparency and societal engagement, ensuring broader ownership of trade policy outcomes.  
ALDE highlights the opportunity to address corruption and tax fairness through parallel EU initiatives, complementing the issue’s development focus with governance reforms.  
ALDE endorses the push for plurilateral agreements like TiSA, which aligns with their vision for dynamic, rules-based trade frameworks that benefit competitive economies.

SD strongly sanctions the issue’s emphasis on strengthening parliamentary oversight of WTO decisions, aligning perfectly with SD’s commitment to democratic legitimacy in global governance through initiatives like the joint EU-Inter-Parliamentary Union conference.  
SD applauds the focus on trade facilitation as a growth catalyst, strongly endorsing binding agreements to streamline customs procedures in line with SD’s advocacy for equitable market access and poverty reduction.  
SD approves the emphasis on concluding the Doha Round’s development pillar, particularly duty-free access for LDCs, which directly advances SD’s priority of addressing systemic trade inequalities through instruments like the Everything but Arms initiative.  
SD proposes strengthening monitoring mechanisms for Aid for Trade commitments to ensure infrastructure funding reaches LDCs as intended, enhancing the issue’s existing call for renewed financial support.  
SD fully sanctions differentiation among developing countries using objective criteria, a position consistent with SD’s long-standing argument against blanket special treatment for advanced economies masquerading as developing nations.

ECR supports the issue’s emphasis on WTO structural reforms to create equitable trade rules but advises explicitly integrating binding anti-counterfeiting measures and geographical indication protections to prevent market distortions.  
ECR endorses differentiation among developing countries but urges stricter application of objective criteria to avoid granting undue advantages to advanced economies like China under S&DT provisions.  
ECR advises amending the issue to prioritize reciprocal treatment for EU industries in trade agreements, ensuring parity in origin denomination recognition and combating "second-tier" status perceptions.  
ECR approves plurilateral agreements like TiSA but proposes accelerated timelines for implementation to counterbalance Doha Round delays and deliver concrete benefits to SMEs.  
ECR stresses the urgency of concluding the Doha Round with measurable outcomes, aligning with the issue’s call for ambition in Bali while addressing non-tariff barriers disproportionately affecting EU exporters.

GUE_NGL entirely againsts the issue's trade facilitation framework for prioritizing export infrastructure over regional development needs, which risks exploiting LDC budgets.  
GUE_NGL rejects the lack of binding financial commitments to build intra-regional trade capacities in developing countries, contrary to their demand for self-determined growth.  
GUE_NGL opposes the issue's silence on dismantling EU agricultural subsidies that undermine Global South farmers, a core Doha principle.  
GUE_NGL condemns support for plurilateral agreements like TiSA as undermining inclusive WTO negotiations, favoring corporate interests over democratic oversight.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue's failure to mandate parliamentary/civil society roles in trade talks, enabling opaque decision-making inconsistent with democratic trade governance.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the urgent need for structural reform of the World Trade Organisation (WTO) to ensure a fair, open, and rules-based multilateral trading system that prioritizes development, particularly for least developed countries (LDCs) and low-income developing nations. It reaffirmed the Doha Development Agenda’s (DDA) objectives of addressing trade imbalances, fostering sustainable growth, and integrating developing countries into global value chains, while stressing the importance of special and differential treatment (S&DT) tailored to varying economic levels. The resolution highlighted the economic potential of a binding trade facilitation agreement, estimating it could boost global GDP by €68 billion annually through streamlined customs procedures, and urged enhanced Aid for Trade initiatives to counter reduced funding in 2011, particularly for infrastructure and capacity-building. It called for concluding the stalled Doha Round with an ambitious outcome at the 2013 Bali Ministerial Conference, emphasizing duty-free, quota-free access for LDCs (as in the EU’s Everything but Arms initiative) and implementation of the LDC services waiver. The Parliament supported plurilateral agreements like the Trade in Services Agreement (TiSA) and the revised Government Procurement Agreement (GPA), while advocating for technology transfers, renewed negotiations on the Information Technology Agreement, and extended TRIPS exemptions for LDCs until 2021. It stressed addressing non-tariff barriers, promoting environmental goods and services, and ensuring policy coherence between trade, development, and climate goals. The resolution also urged differentiation among developing countries based on objective criteria, greater parliamentary oversight of WTO decisions, and strengthened collaboration with international organizations to align trade with broader socio-economic objectives.

title: Trade and investment strategy for the Southern Mediterranean following the Arab Spring revolutions: REPORT on Trade for Change: The EU Trade and Investment Strategy for the Southern Mediterranean following the Arab Spring revolutions
background: The 2010-2011 Arab Spring uprisings reshaped political dynamics in Southern Mediterranean states, prompting EU reassessment of its neighborhood policy under Article 8 TEU. Pre-existing economic disparities, limited regional integration, and prior EU trade frameworks like the Euro-Mediterranean Partnership faced challenges in addressing governance gaps and inclusive growth. The Parliament will discuss revising EU trade and investment approaches to align with democratic transitions, economic stabilization, and enhanced regional cooperation in the Southern Mediterranean.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly upholds the issue’s alignment with democratic transitions through tailored DCFTAs and economic cooperation, reflecting their commitment to stability via market-driven reforms in the Mediterranean.  
EPP approves the focus on agricultural modernization but proposes amending implementation to ensure reciprocal compliance with EU quality and safety standards, protecting both regional food security and sensitive EU sectors.  
EPP endorses micro-enterprise support and civil society engagement as critical to inclusive growth, aligning with their emphasis on grassroots economic empowerment and anti-corruption measures.  
EPP highlights the urgency of increasing EU trade personnel in partner countries to operationalize investment frameworks effectively, reinforcing their priority of technical assistance in democratization processes.  
EPP advocates advancing South-South economic integration as a foundational step for regional cohesion, enhancing the impact of subsequent EU market access initiatives.

EFD rejects the issue's agricultural export focus as firmly challengeing with their principle that such policies risk impoverishing Southern Mediterranean nations by depleting local resources.  
EFD opposes tying trade agreements to bureaucratic frameworks, demanding instead direct SME collaboration to establish grassroots economic training programs led by business owners.  
EFD condemns the top-down regulatory convergence approach, arguing it neglects their core belief in bottom-up development through micro-enterprises and family producers rather than institutional partnerships.  
EFD challenges the issue's migration deterrence strategy, asserting it fails to prioritize immediate economic self-sufficiency measures that would address migration root causes through localized job creation.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of EFD's agenda by substituting private-sector pragmatism with EU institutional mechanisms, which they view as incompatible with effective regional stabilization.

GREEN_EFA rejects the reliance on DCFTAs as fundamentally prioritizing EU agricultural conglomerates over local food sovereignty, exacerbating poverty through export-driven models.  
GREEN_EFA opposes bilateral trade negotiations as inconsistent with their demand for regional cooperation via the Agadir Framework to prevent fragmented economic dependencies.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as binding mechanisms to enforce human rights conditionality, risking continued marginalization of civil society in trade governance.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the issue’s failure to address how agricultural liberalization perpetuates social dumping, directly contradicting their stance on equitable development.  
This fundamentally againsts with GREEN_EFA’s position that trade agreements must require democratization benchmarks and grassroots participation to achieve meaningful justice.

ALDE strongly agrees the DCFTA framework as a catalyst for economic modernization and poverty reduction, aligning perfectly with ALDE's commitment to integrating Mediterranean partners into value chains while upholding democratic conditionality.  
ALDE approves the SME-focused strategy but proposes amending Article 21 to mandate biannual progress reviews on micro-credit accessibility, ensuring alignment with ALDE's entrepreneurship priorities.  
ALDE applauds the visa facilitation provisions for businesspeople, which effectively advance ALDE's cross-border trade objectives while urging faster implementation timelines to match reform momentum.  
ALDE emphasizes enhancing the sustainable development chapter to include binding environmental safeguards, reflecting ALDE's principle that trade integration must parallel ecological modernization.  
ALDE endorses leveraging EIB/EBRD synergies for youth employment programs, directly supporting ALDE's vision of stabilizing the region through economic inclusion for under-25 populations.

SD strongly upholds the integration of human rights conditionality in DCFTAs, aligning with their commitment to democratic transitions and social justice.  
SD approves the focus on youth employment through ICT development, crucial given the region's demographic profile and EU's strategic interests.  
SD endorses agricultural modernization programs that align with EU standards, promoting sustainable rural economies and food security.  
SD highlights the need for comprehensive impact assessments to balance trade reciprocity, particularly in sensitive sectors like Mediterranean agriculture.  
SD welcomes enhanced EBRD involvement as vital for economic reforms that underpin lasting political stability in the region.

GUE/NGL rejects the issue's promotion of free trade agreements as fundamentally incompatible with their anti-imperialist principles and historical critique of EU economic policies.  
GUE/NGL opposes the DCFTA model for perpetuating neocolonial dependency through market deregulation that prioritizes multinational corporations over sovereign development.  
GUE/NGL condemns the "more for more" approach as a continuation of EU exploitation that substitutes genuine self-determination with extractive trade frameworks.  
GUE/NGL demands complete cancellation of odious debts inherited from dictatorships rather than conditional financial assistance through EIB/EBRD programs.  
GUE/NGL asserts that food sovereignty requires public ownership of resources and price controls, rejecting agricultural modernization tied to EU corporate standards.

resolution: The European Parliament raised support for democratic transitions in Southern Mediterranean countries, emphasizing respect for human rights, peaceful assembly, and freedoms of expression, religion, and internet access. It endorsed tailored EU strategies, including Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Areas (DCFTAs) with Egypt, Jordan, Morocco, and Tunisia, tied to conditionality on human rights and mutual accountability. The resolution highlighted economic cooperation through investment frameworks, anti-corruption measures, and synergies with financial institutions like the EIB and EBRD, while stressing energy interconnections and sustainable development. It welcomed Tunisia’s democratic reforms as a regional model and advocated for agricultural modernization, noting that over a third of the workforce in Southern Mediterranean countries relies on agriculture. The EU was urged to support rural development via the European Neighbourhood Facility for Agriculture and Rural Development, aligning production with EU standards, promoting food security, and addressing climate challenges. The resolution called for balanced trade agreements to protect sensitive EU agricultural sectors, avoid social/environmental dumping, and foster youth and women’s inclusion in agriculture. It emphasized regulatory convergence in trade standards, infrastructure improvements, and global cooperation to mitigate food crises, underlining the link between inclusive growth, political stability, and prosperity in the region.

title: EU-Japan Economic Partnership Agreement: RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and Japan for an Economic Partnership
background: The EU and Japan negotiated an Economic Partnership Agreement to strengthen bilateral trade ties amid global protectionist trends, addressing tariff reductions, market access, and sustainable development commitments. The Parliament will discuss ratification of the agreement and its alignment with EU trade policy objectives and international regulatory standards.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly approves the EU-Japan EPA as a strategic victory for rules-based trade, eliminating 99% of tariffs while safeguarding EU agricultural interests through robust geographical indication protections.  
EPP absolutely accepts the agreement’s integration of sustainable development principles, particularly its binding commitment to uphold the Paris Climate Agreement and enforce high environmental standards.  
EPP applauds the dedicated SME chapter as a landmark achievement that will empower small businesses to access Japan’s $5 trillion market, aligning with the party’s 2023 priority of economic democratization.  
EPP proposes expanding the list of protected geographical indications in future reviews to include underrepresented EU regions, ensuring all member states benefit equitably from market access gains.  
EPP emphasizes the agreement’s geopolitical necessity in countering protectionist trends, with David McAllister noting it positions the EU as a "reliable global player" amid rising US-China trade tensions.

ENF fully disapproves the agreement for permitting Japanese industrial fishing fleets to exploit Mediterranean and Polynesian waters, directly conflicting with the issue’s pledge to safeguard EU sovereignty and environmental standards.  
ENF rejects the absence of binding measures to halt illegal Japanese fishing practices, undermining the issue’s commitments to sustainable resource management and the Paris Climate Agreement.  
ENF condemns the Commission’s opaque negotiation process, inconsistent with the issue’s emphasis on fair regulatory cooperation and transparency.  
ENF highlights the failure to prioritize immediate arbitration mechanisms, which weakens enforcement of labor and environmental norms as stipulated in the agreement’s monitoring clauses.  
ENF demands amendments to enforce maritime sovereignty protections and penalize non-compliance, aligning with the issue’s agricultural safeguards and geographical indications.

GREEN_EFA fully condemns the EPA's erosion of municipal democratic autonomy, as it mandates irreversible privatization of public services like water management and regional transport systems.  
GREEN_EFA rejects the agreement's constraints on environmental legislation, which prioritize trade convenience over binding commitments to prevent GMO proliferation and weaken climate crisis responses.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the issue's failure to safeguard regulatory sovereignty, directly conflicting with the party's demand for unconditional rights to strengthen labor protections and banking sector reforms.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the agreement's corporate arbitration mechanisms as incompatible with their constitutional principle that public policy must supersede investor privileges.  
GREEN_EFA disputes the issue's claims about shared environmental values, noting Japan's continued whaling practices and lax chemical regulations remain unaddressed in monitoring provisions.

ALDE strongly advocates the EPA as a landmark achievement in EU-Japan relations, aligning perfectly with ALDE's longstanding commitment to rules-based trade and multilateralism in the face of rising global protectionism.  
ALDE applauds the agreement's integration of sustainable development goals, particularly its reinforcement of Paris Climate Agreement obligations and labor rights, which effectively advance ALDE's priority of embedding high environmental and social standards in trade policy.  
ALDE highlights the strategic necessity of partnering with Japan on cybersecurity, digital economy norms, and regional security challenges, underscoring the issue’s alignment with shared democratic values and geopolitical stability.  
ALDE proposes enhancing future bilateral dialogues to address animal welfare concerns, including Japan’s whaling practices and cosmetic testing policies, as a complementary initiative to strengthen ethical trade dimensions without opposing the agreement’s core provisions.  
ALDE endorses the EPA’s economic benefits for EU agriculture and automotive sectors, emphasizing its balanced approach to tariff elimination and geographical indication protections as critical to fostering equitable growth.

ECR completely endorses the EPA's strategic elevation of EU-Japan relations, perfectly aligning with the party's commitment to rules-based global trade and G20-level economic cooperation.  
ECR strongly accepts the immediate ratification timeline, recognizing the agreement's capacity to solidify Europe's trade leadership and counter protectionist narratives through enhanced market access.  
ECR applauds the binding environmental clauses as a model integration of climate governance with commercial policy, reflecting shared commitments to Paris Agreement implementation.  
ECR emphasizes the agreement's geostrategic value in counterbalancing regional security threats, particularly through reinforced economic ties that complement joint defense priorities.  
ECR commends the issue's safeguards for sensitive agricultural sectors and geographical indications, ensuring competitive fairness while advancing export opportunities.

GUE_NGL rejects the agreement’s failure to mandate Japan’s ratification of core ILO conventions, fully challengeing with their demand for binding labor protections in trade deals.  
GUE_NGL opposes the EPA’s tariff elimination framework for enabling agricultural dumping that accelerates the collapse of small Japanese farms, contradicting claims of "fair competition."  
GUE_NGL condemns the omission of enforceable EU data privacy standards in digital trade provisions, rendering the issue’s "regulatory cooperation" pledges hollow.  
GUE_NGL denounces the lack of concrete funding mechanisms for structural adjustments, exposing workers to job losses while corporations benefit from deregulated value chains.  
GUE_NGL rejects the reliance on voluntary environmental commitments that fail to penalize violations, directly undermining the Paris Agreement alignment touted in the issue.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its consent to the conclusion of the Economic Partnership Agreement (EPA) between the European Union and Japan (07965/2018), formally approving the comprehensive trade deal aimed at liberalizing bilateral trade and investment, eliminating tariffs on most goods, and addressing non-tariff barriers. The resolution endorsed the agreement’s provisions on sustainable development, including commitments to uphold the Paris Climate Agreement, promote labor rights, and enforce environmental standards, while safeguarding EU agricultural interests through protections for sensitive sectors and geographical indications. It emphasized the EPA’s potential to strengthen economic ties, increase market access for EU businesses, and reinforce shared values on fair competition and regulatory cooperation. The Parliament also called for effective implementation and monitoring of the agreement’s clauses, particularly regarding Japan’s adherence to international labor and environmental norms, and instructed its President to transmit the decision to the Council, Commission, and relevant national authorities to finalize ratification.

title: EU-Japan Economic Partnership Agreement (resolution): REPORT containing a motion for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and Japan for an Economic Partnership
background: The EU and Japan negotiated an Economic Partnership Agreement to deepen trade relations amid global protectionist trends, addressing tariff reductions, regulatory alignment, and market access while promoting shared standards in sustainability and labor rights. The Parliament will discuss ratification of the agreement and its strategic implications for bilateral economic cooperation.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly endorses the EPA’s tariff liberalization and SME provisions, aligning perfectly with their commitment to rules-based trade and economic resilience.  
EPP applauds the exclusion of ISDS and emphasis on sustainability, effectively advancing their manifesto priorities for climate action and labor rights.  
EPP endorses the geopolitical alignment with Japan as a counter to unilateralism, reinforcing shared democratic values in multilateral governance.  
EPP proposes amending the GI list to include underrepresented member states’ products, ensuring equitable agricultural market access.  
EPP highlights data protection adequacy as a model for global digital partnerships, urging streamlined references to strengthen mutual trust.

ENF entirely doubts the EPA’s failure to enforce maritime sovereignty protections, directly contradicting the issue’s claims of combating illegal fishing while allowing Japanese industrial fleets to exploit Mediterranean and Pacific resources.  
ENF rejects the agreement’s inadequate transparency in negotiations, inconsistent with Article 12’s emphasis on regulatory cooperation openness, mirroring ENF’s longstanding criticism of opaque EU trade practices.  
ENF condemns the implicit authorization of Japanese overfishing in French territories, violating the issue’s sustainability principles and disregarding ENF’s demand for reciprocal environmental accountability.  
ENF highlights the issue’s neglect of artisanal fishing communities, directly opposing ENF’s commitment to protecting local economies from predatory industrial practices enabled by tariff liberalization.  
ENF disputes the EPA’s credibility in upholding labor standards while ignoring Japan’s unratified ILO conventions on forced labor, a critical omission conflicting with ENF’s anti-exploitation platform.

GREEN_EFA fundamentally doubts the EPA’s erosion of democratic governance, which contradicts their principle of local autonomy by mandating irreversible privatization of public services like healthcare and transport.  
GREEN_EFA rejects the agreement’s constraints on environmental and social legislation, directly conflicting with their demand for unfettered regulatory sovereignty to prioritize ecological and labor protections over trade interests.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the failure to explicitly safeguard against GMO proliferation, undermining their core commitment to agroecological integrity despite the issue’s geographical indication protections.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the EPA’s deregulatory threat to financial stability measures, inconsistent with their anti-corporate-risk stance, as the issue neglects binding safeguards against banking sector liberalization.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the irreversible privatization clauses that strip communities of reclaiming public assets, directly contravening their manifesto pledge to defend communal ownership models.

ALDE strongly upholds the EU-Japan EPA as a landmark achievement that aligns perfectly with ALDE's longstanding commitment to rules-based trade and countering protectionism through strategic partnerships.  
ALDE approves the comprehensive tariff reductions and SME-focused provisions, which effectively advance ALDE's priority of creating economic opportunities while safeguarding sensitive sectors through phased adjustments.  
ALDE applauds the integration of sustainability measures, particularly the binding adherence to the Paris Agreement and ILO standards, as a model for aligning trade policy with environmental and social governance.  
ALDE proposes enhancing future dialogues to address animal testing bans and human rights concerns, suggesting expanded civil society mechanisms to monitor Japan’s progress on death penalty abolition and whaling restrictions.  
ALDE strongly endorses the exclusion of ISDS and the focus on digital economy cooperation, recognizing the agreement’s role in setting global standards consistent with liberal democratic values.

ECR fully upholds the EPA's strategic alignment with rules-based trade, perfectly reflecting ECR's commitment to countering protectionism through ambitious G20-level partnerships.  
ECR perfectly aligns with the agreement's tariff elimination framework, recognizing its critical role in securing EU automotive sector access while maintaining sensitive agricultural safeguards.  
ECR fully upholds the exclusion of ISDS mechanisms, affirming this decision as essential to preserving national regulatory sovereignty in trade disputes.  
ECR perfectly aligns with the issue's emphasis on SME competitiveness, particularly the dedicated chapter enabling 78% of EU exporters to expand Japanese market penetration.  
ECR fully upholds the EPA's integration of UNECE automotive standards, recognizing this harmonization as vital for EU-Japan industrial cooperation against global trade fragmentation.

GUE_NGL rejects the EPA for accelerating economic integration without binding mechanisms to protect workers from automation-driven job losses, directly contradicting their commitment to social justice.  
GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the agreement’s failure to mandate Japan’s ratification of ILO Convention 105 on forced labor, rendering its labor standards pledges hollow and incompatible with fair trade principles.  
GUE_NGL condemns the tariff elimination on EU agricultural exports as a threat to Japanese small farmers, exacerbating inequality and contradicting claims of promoting "just globalization" in the issue.  
GUE_NGL highlights the exclusion of EU data protection standards from the agreement’s value chain provisions, creating loopholes for corporate exploitation inconsistent with digital rights priorities.  
GUE_NGL denounces the projected €1.6 billion EU tariff revenue loss as austerity-enabling, directly opposing their anti-neoliberal fiscal agenda and 2030 SDG funding requirements.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the strategic importance of the EU-Japan Economic Partnership Agreement (EPA), covering nearly a third of global GDP, 40% of world trade, and over 600 million people, as a counter to protectionism and a commitment to rules-based trade. It highlighted tariff liberalization, with 99% of EU and 97% of Japanese tariff lines to be eliminated, including phased reductions for automobiles over seven years, while safeguarding sensitive sectors through quotas or staging. The agreement addresses non-tariff barriers in sectors like automotive, food safety, and cosmetics, aligns Japan’s automotive standards with UNECE norms, and protects 205 EU geographical indications (GIs), with potential for expansion. It ensures access to Japan’s public procurement markets for 54 cities, removes barriers for EU rail suppliers, and emphasizes sustainability, including adherence to the Paris Agreement, combating illegal logging and fishing, and promoting ILO core labor standards, with Japan urged to ratify remaining conventions on discrimination and forced labor. The EPA includes a dedicated SME chapter to support 78% of EU exporters to Japan, provisions for data protection adequacy, and safeguards for public services and regulatory autonomy, including the precautionary principle. Parliament stressed monitoring implementation, including ex-post sustainability assessments, enforcement of environmental and labor commitments, and transparency in regulatory cooperation, while calling for enhanced civil society involvement and improved tools to mitigate globalization’s impacts. The resolution also welcomed the exclusion of investor-state dispute settlement (ISDS) and emphasized future cooperation on multilateral trade rules and digital economy standards.

title: EU-Singapore Free Trade Agreement: RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Free Trade Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Singapore
background: The EU and Singapore negotiated a free trade agreement and investment protection pact over a decade, reflecting Singapore's role as a key ASEAN trade hub and the EU's pursuit of updated economic partnerships in Asia. The Parliament will discuss ratification of these agreements, addressing trade liberalization, investment frameworks, and regulatory alignment.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly accepts the EU-Singapore FTA's tariff elimination and €550 million economic boost, perfectly aligning with their commitment to open markets and job creation.  
EPP applauds the binding labor rights provisions requiring Singapore's ratification of ILO conventions, effectively advancing their priority of value-based trade policy.  
EPP endorses the permanent bilateral investment court system as a transformative model that replaces outdated ISDS mechanisms, matching their 2023 trade modernization goals.  
EPP highlights Singapore's role as an ASEAN gateway, strongly accepting the agreement's geopolitical value in countering protectionism and strengthening EU-Asia ties.  
EPP proposes accelerating future FTA ratification timelines through procedural reforms while fully approving this agreement's thorough legal vetting process.

ENF rejects fundamentally the tariff elimination provisions, arguing they enable Asian imports to destabilize European industries through Singapore's role as a conduit for Chinese goods.  
ENF opposes the agreement's sustainability claims, highlighting Singapore's presence on tax haven watchlists and failure to adopt EU labor/environmental standards.  
ENF condemns the financial services liberalization as creating loopholes for opaque banking practices and profit shifting by multinational corporations.  
ENF disputes the issue's counterfeit protections, noting Singapore's lack of geographic indication registries leaves Italian producers vulnerable to copied goods.  
ENF warns the pact institutionalizes Singapore as China's EU-facing trade platform, bypassing quality controls and flooding markets with substandard products.

GREEN_EFA rejects the inclusion of investment protection agreements that create privileged legal avenues for multinational corporations, directly contradicting their commitment to democratic sovereignty and public interest safeguards.  
GREEN_EFA opposes fundamentally the arbitration mechanisms allowing Singapore-based firms to challenge EU member states' environmental and public health policies, which undermines judicial transparency and citizen rights.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the failure to exclude public debt restructuring from investor-state dispute settlements, creating unacceptable loopholes that prioritize financial speculators over sovereign debt issue frameworks.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the agreement's alignment with tax haven structures and authoritarian governance models, directly conflicting with their mandate to combat fiscal injustice and promote human rights.  
GREEN_EFA demands complete removal of Annex 4 provisions on public debt as a prerequisite for any future consideration, asserting that current terms dangerously erode EU financial crisis management protocols.

SD supports the agreement's emphasis on sustainable development and Singapore's commitments to ILO conventions, while advising stricter enforcement timelines for labor rights implementation.  
SD expresses concern about the lack of binding sanctions for non-compliance with labor standards, proposing amendments to link market access to verified ratification of all core ILO conventions.  
SD advises replacing the ISDS mechanism with a permanent multilateral investment court system to prevent corporate privilege over public interests, referencing concerns raised about investor-state disputes.  
SD endorses the ASEAN gateway strategy and tariff elimination benefits for SMEs but requests biannual monitoring of Singapore's progress on Paris Agreement climate benchmarks.  
SD highlights the need for enhanced transparency in financial regulations, urging specific provisions to address Singapore's high Financial Secrecy Index ranking through joint anti-tax-evasion task forces.

ECR strongly approves the EU-Singapore FTA as a strategic advancement of global free trade, aligning with their longstanding commitment to expanding Commonwealth economic partnerships post-Brexit.  
ECR applauds the agreement's role in establishing EU leadership in trade liberalization and technological collaboration with key ASEAN partners.  
ECR highlights the FTA's potential to eliminate tariffs and create optimal conditions for EU industries, exemplified by major corporate investments like Dyson's Singapore operations.  
ECR emphasizes the importance of replicating this model with Vietnam and other ASEAN nations to maximize EU trade competitiveness.  
ECR proposes enhancing labor rights monitoring mechanisms and revising ISDS provisions to address fair competition concerns while maintaining core market access benefits.

GUE_NGL rejects fundamentally the inclusion of ISDS mechanisms that enable corporate challenges to democratic policymaking, directly contradicting their anti-neoliberal governance principles.  
GUE_NGL opposes the agreement's failure to enforce sustainability obligations while granting investor privileges, creating dangerous asymmetries in environmental protection.  
GUE_NGL condemns legitimizing Singapore's tax haven status through enhanced financial market access, undermining EU commitments to fiscal justice.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue's incompatibility with social welfare priorities by permitting foreign bondholders to obstruct sovereign debt restructuring during crises.  
GUE_NGL denounces the institutionalization of corporate supremacy through non-binding labor clauses paired with legally actionable investor rights.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its approval for the conclusion of the EU-Singapore Free Trade Agreement, endorsing the draft Council decision (07971/2018) and the agreement text (07972/2018) under the legal bases of Articles 91, 100(2), 207(4), and 218(6) and (7) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. The resolution affirmed compliance with the Court of Justice of the EU’s opinion of 16 May 2017, which confirmed the EU’s exclusive competence over most aspects of the agreement. It highlighted the Committee on International Trade’s recommendation (A8-0053/2019) supporting the deal, which aims to enhance trade relations, eliminate tariffs, and address non-tariff barriers while promoting sustainable development and labor rights. The Parliament instructed its President to communicate its consent to the Council, Commission, and relevant national governments and parliaments, finalizing the ratification process.

title: EU-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (resolution): REPORT containing a motion for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Free Trade Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Singapore
background: The EU and Singapore, key trade partners with significant economic ties, initiated FTA negotiations in 2009 following broader ASEAN engagement efforts. The Court of Justice clarified EU competence in 2017, enabling progress. The Parliament will discuss ratifying the EU-Singapore Free Trade Agreement and associated investment and partnership agreements.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly agrees the EU-Singapore FTA as a strategic gateway to ASEAN markets, aligning with its commitment to expanding global trade networks and reinforcing Europe’s economic influence in Asia.  
EPP applauds the agreement’s tariff elimination and SME-focused provisions, which directly advance its priority of securing export opportunities for 83% of EU businesses operating in Singapore.  
EPP endorses the innovative Investment Protection Agreement, highlighting its reformed dispute settlement mechanism as a model for future agreements that balance investor rights with regulatory sovereignty.  
EPP recognizes the binding commitments on labor rights and environmental standards, particularly Singapore’s pledge to ratify core ILO conventions, as aligning with its values-driven trade agenda.  
EPP proposes streamlining future FTA ratification processes to avoid multi-year delays while maintaining rigorous legal scrutiny, ensuring quicker access to emerging markets without compromising quality.

EFDD rejects the issue due to its inclusion of investor-state dispute settlement mechanisms, which fully against with EFDD's principle that corporations must not override national laws through supranational tribunals.  
EFDD opposes the investment agreement's arbitration system as irreconcilable with democratic governance, citing precedents like CETA where such frameworks empower multinationals over public interest.  
EFDD highlights the issue's failure to address sovereignty risks posed by parallel justice systems for foreign investors, directly contradicting EFDD's manifesto commitment to legislative supremacy.  
EFDD condemns the lack of binding enforcement for environmental and labor standards, rendering sustainability pledges ineffective compared to corporate litigation privileges.  
EFDD rejects the conflation of trade liberalization with investor protections, demanding strict separation of market access provisions from ISDS mechanisms to avoid systemic democratic erosion.

ENF firmly disapproves the agreement as it surrenders European economic sovereignty to Asian manufacturing hubs, directly conflicting with ENF's protectionist trade principles.  
ENF rejects the inadequate safeguards against counterfeit product influx from third countries through Singapore, noting the issue fails to mandate customs verification protocols for regional supply chains.  
ENF condemns the agreement's facilitation of Chinese market penetration through Singapore's 75% ethnic Chinese population and China-linked re-export structures, threatening domestic industries with substandard goods.  
ENF opposes the flawed geographical indication protections requiring EU producers to initiate legal actions individually rather than establishing automatic recognition through Singaporean registries.  
ENF denounces the financial services provisions enabling regulatory arbitrage through Singapore's opaque banking sector, overlooking its OECD grey-list status as a tax haven.

GREEN_EFA rejects the inclusion of Annex 4 on public debt restructuring in the investment protection agreement, which firmly condemns with the party's principle of equitable financial governance by granting privileged veto powers to Singapore-based investors over EU sovereign debt issues.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the arbitration tribunal mechanism as inconsistent with democratic accountability, noting its failure to prevent multinationals from challenging environmental protections and public health policies through clauses contradicting the issue's claimed regulatory autonomy safeguards.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the agreement's critical oversight in addressing Singapore's restrictions on press freedom and assembly rights, directly opposing the issue's stated commitment to labor rights and civil society engagement.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the prioritization of corporate sovereignty over citizen welfare through IPA provisions that undermine the Paris Agreement alignment by enabling legal challenges to climate policies.  
GREEN_EFA demands full removal of Articles 12-14 governing investor-state disputes before any parliamentary approval, citing irreconcilable contradictions with the Green New Deal's prohibition on extrajudicial corporate tribunals.

ECR strongly upholds the EUSFTA as a strategic advancement of free trade principles, aligning with its commitment to expanding EU competitiveness in ASEAN markets through bilateral agreements.  
ECR applauds the elimination of technical barriers and tariff provisions, which directly benefit 83% SME exporters and reinforce Singapore’s role as a critical regional hub for EU firms.  
ECR proposes strengthening enforcement mechanisms for labor rights provisions to accelerate Singapore’s ratification of core ILO conventions, framing this as an enhancement opportunity rather than opposition.  
ECR highlights the agreement’s alignment with fiscal responsibility by safeguarding financial stability through prudential carve-outs, a longstanding ECR priority in trade deals.  
ECR notes the issue’s value as a template for future ASEAN agreements but suggests prioritizing Vietnam FTA ratification to maintain momentum in trade liberalization.

GUE_NGL firmly doubts the inclusion of ISDS mechanisms, enabling corporate challenges to democratic governance and prioritizing investor interests over public welfare, directly contradicting commitments to the rule of law.  
GUE_NGL rejects the agreement’s failure to enforce binding environmental and labor standards, rendering sustainability commitments ineffective and undermining ecological and social protections.  
GUE_NGL condemns provisions allowing foreign investors to purchase state bonds, risking financial instability and obstructing sovereign debt restructuring during crises.  
GUE_NGL highlights the contradiction in partnering with Singapore, a recognized tax haven, which conflicts with EU anti-tax evasion efforts and transparency principles.  
GUE_NGL opposes private arbitration tribunals favoring corporations, perpetuating inequality by sidelining workers’ rights and public services.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the strategic and economic significance of the EU-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (EUSFTA), emphasizing its role as the first bilateral trade deal with an ASEAN member and a precedent for future ASEAN agreements. The agreement, which eliminates Singapore’s remaining tariffs on EU goods and removes trade barriers like double safety tests for cars and electronics, is projected to boost bilateral trade volumes by 10% over five years, with Singapore’s GDP potentially increasing by 0.94% (€2.7 billion) and the EU’s by €550 million annually. It grants EU firms enhanced access to Singapore’s services sector (financial, telecom, engineering) and public procurement markets, protects 190 EU geographical indications (GIs), and ensures zero duties on agri-food exports (€2.2 billion in 2016). The resolution highlights commitments to sustainability, including alignment with the Paris Agreement, labor rights (urging Singapore to ratify core ILO conventions), and civil society involvement through advisory groups. It notes Singapore’s role as a regional hub (hosting 10,000 EU firms, 50,000 EU exporters, 83% SMEs) and addresses competitive parity with other major economies (US, China, Japan) that already have FTAs with Singapore. The agreement safeguards EU regulatory autonomy, upholds public services, and includes a prudential carve-out for financial stability, while calling for stronger enforcement of environmental and labor provisions through a review clause.

title: EU-Singapore Investment Protection Agreement: RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council decision on the conclusion on behalf of the European Union of the Investment Protection Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Singapore, of the other part
background: The EU and Singapore negotiated agreements on investment protection, trade, and partnership following the 2017 Court of Justice opinion clarifying EU competence, replacing existing bilateral investment treaties and addressing Singapore's role as a regional trade hub. The Parliament will discuss the legal and economic implications of concluding these agreements.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly promotes the establishment of the permanent Investment Tribunal system with appellate review, aligning perfectly with their commitment to replace outdated ISDS mechanisms through judicialized dispute issue.  
EPP approves the agreement's safeguards for regulatory autonomy on public health and environmental policies, effectively advancing their principle of balancing investor rights with sovereign policymaking.  
EPP endorses the binding code of conduct for tribunal members as a critical enhancement to ethical standards in trade agreements, directly implementing their 2023 manifesto pledge for transparent adjudication.  
EPP highlights Singapore's role as an ASEAN trade gateway, strongly promoteing the agreement's geopolitical value in countering protectionism and anchoring EU standards in Southeast Asia.  
EPP proposes accelerating timelines for future multilateral investment court negotiations while fully backing this agreement's interim tribunal model as a progressive step.

ENF rejects the agreement as absolutely againsting with its principle of economic sovereignty, citing Singapore's role as a conduit for Chinese exports that bypass European quality standards.  
ENF opposes the tribunal system for failing to address Singapore's status as a tax haven gray-listed jurisdiction, directly contradicting ENF's anti-globalist fiscal policies.  
ENF condemns the agreement's geographic indication provisions for shifting enforcement burdens to EU businesses rather than mandating automatic protections.  
ENF argues the issue overlooks critical risks of counterfeit product influx through Singapore's manufacturing hubs, undermining Italy's industrial base despite Article 12 safeguards.  
ENF rejects the financial services liberalization as enabling regulatory arbitrage against EU banking rules, consistent with its opposition to supranational economic governance.

GREEN_EFA rejects the agreement for creating investor privileges in public debt restructuring through Annex 4, fundamentally rejecting with their stance against corporate capture of sovereign financial governance.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the tribunal system as incompatible with democratic principles, citing risks of multinationals challenging environmental and public health policies through ISDS mechanisms.  
This fundamentally rejects with GREEN_EFA's position that trade agreements must never subordinate states' regulatory autonomy to corporate litigation threats.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as Singapore's status as a tax haven and its restrictions on press freedom, contradicting GREEN_EFA's human rights conditionality requirements.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the agreement's failure to exclude arbitration for debt disputes, directly enabling financial speculation against public interest as seen in post-2008 crisis frameworks.

SD supports the agreement's establishment of transparent tribunals and ethical standards but advises amending Article 12 to include binding timelines for Singapore’s ratification of ILO core labor conventions.  
SD endorses the prohibition of parallel proceedings as a step toward fair dispute issue but proposes accelerating multilateral investment court (MIC) negotiations via a dedicated annex.  
SD approves the safeguards against regulatory chill but recommends strengthening Article 7 by requiring mandatory sustainability impact assessments every three years.  
SD acknowledges the economic complementarity with Singapore but urges revising Clause 4(b) to cap investor compensation claims, preventing excessive fiscal burdens on public policy measures.  
SD highlights concerns about the Appellate Tribunal’s limited jurisdiction over labor rights violations, suggesting a protocol to align its mandate with SD’s 2023 trade justice pledges.

ECR strongly promotes the permanent Investment Tribunal framework as aligning with their commitment to rule-based trade systems, proposing enhanced labor standard verification mechanisms to address wage dumping concerns.  
ECR approves the transparency provisions requiring public document disclosure, suggesting quarterly implementation reports to strengthen accountability without delaying ratification.  
ECR highlights the agreement's strategic value in advancing EU-ASEAN economic ties, urging accelerated conclusion of parallel agreements with Vietnam to maximize regional synergies.  
ECR acknowledges ISDS modernization efforts while recommending explicit exclusion of death penalty-related investments to address human rights alignment concerns.  
 While majority ECR voices endorse the agreement’s trade liberalization goals, one member’s criticism of regulatory balance is reframed as a proposal to expand Annex II’s public policy carveouts.

GUE_NGL rejects the inclusion of ISDS mechanisms under the Investment Tribunal system, which perpetuates corporate privilege over democratic governance by allowing foreign investors to challenge public interest regulations.  
GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the failure to impose binding sustainability obligations on investors, creating legal asymmetry that prioritizes profit over environmental and social protections outlined in Articles 4-6.  
GUE_NGL condemns the agreement's authorization of foreign ownership of sovereign debt instruments, enabling financial speculators to obstruct debt restructuring during economic crises as per Clause 3.2(b).  
GUE_NGL highlights the contradiction in partnering with Singapore's authoritarian regime and tax haven status, undermining EU commitments to fiscal transparency and human rights stated in the issue's preamble.  
GUE_NGL denounces the exclusion of enforceable labor standards, rendering the "right to regulate" provisions in Section 2.4 ineffective against corporate-driven regulatory chill.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its consent to the conclusion of the EU-Singapore Investment Protection Agreement, which establishes a modern framework for investment disputes through a permanent Investment Tribunal of First Instance and an Appellate Tribunal. The tribunals will comprise members appointed by both parties, requiring expertise in public international law, judicial qualifications, and adherence to strict ethical standards via a binding code of conduct. The agreement ensures transparency through public hearings and document disclosure, safeguards the right of parties to regulate public health, environmental protection, and other policy objectives to mitigate regulatory chill, and prohibits parallel proceedings and abusive claims. It includes provisions on fair and equitable treatment, anti-discrimination, and rules governing direct and indirect expropriation. Additionally, the parties committed to pursuing a multilateral investment court (MIC) to further reform investor-state dispute resolution globally.

title: EU-Singapore Investment Protection Agreement (resolution): REPORT containing a motion for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion on behalf of the European Union of the Investment Protection Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Singapore, of the other part
background: The EU pursued ASEAN trade negotiations under 2007 directives, shifted to bilateral talks with Singapore in 2009, and addressed legal competence via a 2017 ECJ opinion while updating member states' bilateral investment treaties. The Parliament will discuss concluding the EU-Singapore Investment Protection Agreement.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly sanctions the modernized Investment Protection Agreement as a transformative upgrade from outdated bilateral treaties, aligning perfectly with EPP's commitment to rule-based trade governance and the Investment Court System.  
EPP approves the binding ethical codes and appellate mechanism for dispute issue, effectively advancing EPP's priority of legal certainty while safeguarding regulatory autonomy in environmental and public health matters.  
EPP highlights Singapore's strategic role as an ASEAN gateway, noting the agreement’s €550 million projected economic boost as critical for EU competitiveness in Asia-Pacific markets.  
EPP proposes streamlining future agreement ratification processes to avoid procedural delays, enhancing the EU’s capacity to swiftly conclude mutually beneficial trade partnerships.  
EPP applauds Singapore’s formal commitment to ILO conventions and multilateral investment court principles, which resonate with EPP’s manifesto goals for global trade reform.

EFDD rejects the Investment Protection Agreement's tribunal system as perpetuating corporate supremacy over democratic governance, completely rejecting with EFDD's opposition to ISDS mechanisms.  
EFDD opposes granting multinationals legal avenues to challenge public health and environmental regulations, undermining national sovereignty protections central to EFDD's platform.  
The proposal overlooks critical accountability gaps by failing to impose binding human rights obligations on investors, contradicting EFDD's demands for corporate responsibility frameworks.  
EFDD condemns the agreement's negotiation opacity and last-minute disclosure of geographical indication conflicts, inconsistent with transparency pledges in EFDD's trade policy principles.  
This framework's structural alignment with EU institutional delays clashes with EFDD's advocacy for agile, nation-state-led trade models exemplified by post-Brexit Singapore-UK prospects.

ENF fundamentally rejects the agreement's replacement of bilateral treaties, arguing it surrenders national sovereignty to multinational corporate interests through the ICS framework.  
ENF opposes opening EU markets to Singaporean financial services, warning this enables circumvention of European fiscal regulations given Singapore's status on tax haven watchlists.  
ENF condemns the failure to impose binding human rights obligations on investors, directly contradicting the issue's claim of safeguarding public policy regulation.  
ENF highlights the agreement's threat to geographical indication protections, exposing Italian and French producers to counterfeit goods repackaged via Singapore.  
ENF warns the pact serves as a proxy for Chinese economic expansion, with 65% of Singaporean exports originating from China, undermining EU manufacturing standards.

GREEN_EFA rejects the agreement's inclusion of public debt restructuring loopholes in Annex 4, which privilege Singaporean investors over EU sovereign debt procedures and contradict fiscal justice principles.  
GREEN_EFA opposes fundamentally the Investment Court System as an undemocratic transfer of sovereignty enabling Singaporean multinationals to challenge environmental and public health regulations through corporate tribunals.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the absence of binding human rights obligations for investors, directly conflicting with the party's 2022 manifesto mandate for corporate accountability in trade agreements.  
GREEN_EFA denounces the agreement's reinforcement of Singapore's authoritarian model, which systematically violates press freedom and assembly rights central to GREEN_EFA's democracy-first foreign policy.  
GREEN_EFA refuses to endorse forum shopping risks that disadvantage European SMEs, echoing the party's longstanding opposition to ISDS mechanisms that institutionalize corporate power over public interest.

ECR strongly sanctions the Investment Protection Agreement's replacement of bilateral treaties with a permanent Investment Court System, aligning perfectly with ECR's commitment to transparent, rules-based dispute issue.  
ECR applauds the agreement's safeguards for regulatory autonomy on public health and environmental standards, effectively advancing ECR's priority of balancing market access with sovereign policymaking.  
ECR welcomes Singapore's openness to a multilateral investment court as a model for global reform, consistent with ECR's advocacy for institutional coherence in trade governance.  
ECR proposes enhancing corporate accountability by urging binding EU legislation on human rights due diligence, mirroring the issue's own emphasis on UN business accountability frameworks.   
ECR emphasizes rigorous enforcement of anti-dumping measures through the agreement’s dispute mechanisms to address concerns about labor standard circumvention and third-country transshipment.

GUE/NGL fully disputes the Investment Court System as a repackaged ISDS mechanism enabling corporate challenges to public health and environmental regulations, perpetuating profit-over-people adjudication.
